author: Zack Hames
content: Artist just sent me masters of a mix I did for them - and it sounds *horrible*. The did something insane with the stereo image that made all of the super wide stuff basically go to the middle. It sounds like a mistake or improper use of a widener. On top of that, there is zero punch in the snare and they made everything STUPID bright. (I mix bright as it is). I'll let those things "slide" because they are sort of  a matter of taste. Anyway, I told the artist I thought the stereo image was fucked up. What's the best approach to telling them I generally think the master(s) are horrible? Should I just let it go? Should I tell them politely I think there might be a mistake? (First time dealing with this tbh!)

author: Zack Hames
content:
DM me man! So far I probed, simply asking if they added a guitar (it sounded like they put the raw guitar OVER the mix) he said they didn't. I eventually could hear it was a mangled version of my mix. I essentially told him, respectfully, it seems like a mistake was made with the stereo image. Then later gently mentioned that the snare was completely missing / had no punch. He listened back and forth and agreed with both points. He ultimately said he just listened and thought it sounded good and didn't' bother to compare.  (He's a super easy going / nice artist)

Anyway, I am just trying not to shit all over this guy. I don't want to be a dick at ALL, it's a local engineer and everything. You make a good point of simply asking them what they think first. I had such a visceral emotional reaction, it was hard not to just be like "this sounds horrible, this cannot be what gets released".

I am sure this happens a LOT.

author: Rollmottle
content: Do you have direct contact with the ME or is the artist handling that?

author: Zack Hames
content: Great question - Artist is handling that. He's friend with the ME. I did 1 of the mixes on a 4 song EP. I understand compromises may need to be made when you do mixes in 3 different places/people/etc. but this was ridiculous.

author: Rollmottle
content: that's a rough situation. if the artist is happy and you don't have the ME's ear, not a whole lot you can do here other than voice your concerns to the artist. i think you can approach it from a technical level to leave all the emotion and taste out of it -- "hey, it really sounds like there's a technical issue here, can you double check with the ME or put me in touch with them...want to make sure your shit is the best it can be..." kind of thing

author: Rollmottle
content: the deadline is probably bullshit 😬 ...just sayin'...it's music, it's probably self-imposed and if it's not, it's likely arbitrary and another day or two isn't going to be world-ending

author: BillyC
content: @Eric Martin I think you hit the nail on the head with that second sentence. I'm just seeing too many engineers that don't have accurate judgement on how far the song in front of them actually needs to go, whether it's 5% or 85%. Instead they work off of some misguided preconception of what they think they're  "supposed " to do in their role, either because it worked on their last project that was in a completely different state or because of some garbage youtube video claiming one specific way of doing something as the end-all be-all.

author: Rollmottle
content: Huge, colossal mistake and it doesn't cost that much in the grand scheme of a record or gear. People tend not to have great perspective when they don't know why they should master in the first place. The myriad numbskulls and YT producers out on the internet offering uninformed opinions don't help.

that totally makes sense. @Slow Hand talked it about it at some point i think?

basically if you're manipulating audio, it will be different at 192 for sure. dropping things an octave with certain algorithms at 192 (or 88, 96) will retain high end differently thank 44 or 48 because you're starting with much more high end information.

content: You just hame more granular control over what is happening in the salected frequencies, rather than one setting for all.

author: cuba1956
content: But depending on his material, he's probably not wrong about what is happening in general.

author: cuba1956
content: True, but if you think of final signal as = Vin * ((threshold - peak) * ratio). With lower peak and higher signal (that's what he did, based on the video), you get louder result ( -the bass he removed).

author: cuba1956
content: So you get everything louder, but the bass is lower than before.

author: cuba1956
content: Depending on material, he sees it as midrange increase.

author: cuba1956
content: With multiband you can do the same thing if you divide the signal (which is a crossover), make the low end level smaller and bring the overall level a bit up.

author: cuba1956
content:
I rewatched it to make sure maybe I've missed something, but it seems like it's what he's doing. Reshaping the signal a bit to be able to trigger less compression with lows and highs. Then makes the mix louder. So mid become more compressed than lows and highs. 
I think he just doesn't explain it well and it's been edited like shit.

author: ehutton21
content: Man I gotta think Luca knows what he’s doing. He’s really respected, that video is clearly cut together, and I think the captions are trying to reflect the gist of the idea rather than a detailed nuance. And for whatever it’s worth, I know this discord is like the holy grail of knowledge but Luca’s mixlabs aren’t awful by any means. This site is like if all the good aspects of gearspace and Reddit sub forums merged with reputable engineers and producers with active profiles in their communities, which is a resource that really doesn’t exist for many people at all outside here. I literally knew one other person who I could maybe ask questions about mixing techniques before I found these podcasts (and even then it took me like a month and a half to join up here, I’m anxious lol!)

author: cuba1956
content: I'm completely with you on that. I've been going deep into compression for the past 5+ years or so: spent probably 100+ hours hovering over various schematics — diode bridge, optical, varimu, fet, pmw, etc; built hardware and software compressors myself and I still learn new things which should've been apparent in hindsight.

author: cuba1956
content: I think it's a perfect example of simple, yet complicated concept.

author: Will Melones
content: Totally comforting. I started working for a producer once, knowing that he wasn’t really ‘into’ the tech side of engineering but was very successful and effective at his job. He asked me for advice on some routing thing or another, and I told him how I would do it, prefacing that this probably wasn’t the “super pro” way to go about it—I don’t remember what the task was, but imagine throwing a reverb on as an insert rather than creating an aux for it, something like that. And his response was “I think the super pro way to do anything is whatever you’re comfortable with that gets the job done.”

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Generally you are trading off two competing things - a loud intro is great and ear catching but undermines the lift into the bridge or chorus. So you balance that, or do subtle rides

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
Ah gotcha, that makes sense! I find myself always wanting to make the intro and Verse 1 quiet and narrow so the lift is good, but by the end of the mix, Im always a little concerned if im going to "scare" the listener because the chorus hits so loud.

Good to know, as with everything, it's just a trust your ears kind of thing.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Real musical lift is magic, not interesting or useful but genuinely 2+2=5

author: Rollmottle
content: That’s usually the natural course of where things end up in a pop song. Even the “quieter” parts of the latter part of a song are louder on paper than the same part earlier, but in context sound right louder.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Don’t be afraid to cheat away a half or full dB slowly during a verse to get a pop at the bridge or chorus

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Or the opposite to ride up the top of the song and slowly fade back to 0dB for the chorus (or 4 bars before)

author: peterlabberton
content: The majority of the time I don’t have a say in the mastering these days unless it’s a project I’m producing (mostly mixing or tracking drums or other piecemeal things). So it’s kind of self-selecting for experiences that I’m particularly invested in when I actually interface with mastering. And therefore, I’ve really appreciated the moments when people can just let it be and act as quality control.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: As an aside I think recording and mixing for 18 years before I committed to mastering only is/was mostly a negative. But the one thing it did give me was a deep understanding of just how lost you can be at the end of making a record, and how little perspective you can have. That empathy helps me in my day to day work

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Again, I’m trying to communicate big ideas with ineloquent and sleepy thumbs.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Last thought, really connecting with the fact that the magic comes downstream from song and performance is also freeing. Beating yourself over the head trying to inject “magic” against the odds is soul destroying. Putting that aside and opening your field of vision to spot the magic (even in it’s most nascent form) allows you to start nurturing and highlighting the good stuff

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So, even though I never really sound like it when I write, my way of looking at this is net positive and not negative. Be open to Receive the gifts of great art (or just the seed of it), and unburden yourself from trying to make it at the wrong stage of the process (mastering)

content: https://discord.com/channels/800115582531928064/806966263086972939/1035590257485303888 @Nomograph Mastering let’s talk

author: 1ggy
content: How was you approach different than doing a 8-10 song record? What other valuable nuances are there to consider?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Ok, we have half a cup of coffee worth of time 🙂

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: **So, some mastering strategies for long projects**

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: A couple of considerations first

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: 2) I think homogeneity in sonics is overplayed in mastering, generally

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: It seems a lot of mastering people see theIr job as finding and zapping differences between songs

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I definitely labored under that belief for a long time. But the reality is the average listener just does not hop around tracks like we can in the studio

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So the difference / disjunction threshold for what loses their attention is higher

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But wait! Sometimes that not fitting is just the perfect break from the drudgery of sameness, so be careful. You may actually want to enhance the differences rather than delete them

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Make note of tracks that are underwhelming or need something and then you can give them the extra love they need

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Does that make sense?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Oh, your question of how is it different to an 8 or 10 song record? Honestly probably not that different but I probably have a wider angle view of the whole while I'm working, the bar for each track "hitting" is lower

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Let me know if you have any questions, now that I look at this it's all mighty obvious

author: 1ggy
content: That makes a lot of sense thanks for sharing!

author: 1ggy
content: My fear is that a lot of the tracks may be rough mixes with an expectation that a lot “fixing” will be done in mastering. Is it out of line to ask to hear the mixes first before committing? This is not a major label artist.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Definitely not out of line to ask

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I've spent years down every multiband parallel upward expanding FFT based inverting saturated dynamic equalizer rabbit hole

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I do reach for special tools occasionally, but way less that the internet will have you believe

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: They loved V2 but there wasn't a multiband in sight

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: It was absolutely not what the track needed, so give them the outcome but allow yourself to control the path to the destination free of expectation

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Maybe?! Or it could just be the tool he's familiar with to get the result he wanted. But I knew a better way to the desired destination for this track at least (shock horror it was one band of EQ)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Whatever the mixes are just really try to love them, and encourage them to be their best

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Good luck and let us know how it goes!

author: 1ggy
content: That's great perspective, thanks!

author: Adam Thein
content:
Oh one other big caveat with Discord voice chat on Mac - for whatever reason the Discord app on Mac doesn't play well with audio interfaces as inputs.   It's a known and unresolved issue in the app: https://support.discord.com/hc/en-us/articles/360040580711-Audio-Interface-Issues-on-macOS

If someone is able to get this working I'd love to hear about it!  It does not work correctly with my Motu Ultralite mk5 so if I'm on Mac I've been using the built-in mic.  Works fine with airpods I believe.

author: Rollmottle
content: I don't have anything very specific to offer you. I would keep this in mind though: just make the songs become what they need to become. They may need more than a "subtle approach" to become what they need to become. Don't let that little nugget color what the songs are telling you they need if it means going well past the edge of subtle (whatever that means to them and to you). They won't know or care if that's what's needed to make the outcome great. Clear as mud...😬 😇

author: Chris Doms
content: Thanks man, I appreciate that. I can even see how wording it that way in my brain could become constraining if I’m not mindful about it.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Your key challenge will be mixer brain, the (normally useful!) impulse to mix/change balances etc. Mastering is not the place for that. So the first move will be “Loving what is” in the words of the great Byron Katie

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Second challenge will be option paralysis, 1000 plug ins and possible processing changes. I suggest taking all of those options off of the table

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Then line up your songs in the DAW. Use clip gain or whatever your equivalent is to reduce the level to peaking around -6 dBFS then by ear match the level of each track. You should be able to jump around and have things fairly consistent already in terms of level

Steven Pruitt (born April 17, 1984) is an American Wikipedia editor with the highest number of edits made to the English Wikipedia, at over 5 million, having made at least one edit to one-third of all English Wikipedia articles. author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah. The human curation is imperfect and set up in a way where truth (in the editorial sense) is weighted more towards whatever certain mainstream outlets are reporting (because of how the citation system prioritizes certain sources).

I think a good rule of thumb for anyone reading Wikipedia is that it's reliable for technical topics (that we'd consider to be objective), while you really ought to get information about contentious stuff from more direct sources.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I think it’s easy to be cynical about Wikipedia, or any institution really. And I started the cynical ball rolling here (while saying I didn’t want things to get political). Like almost everything Wikipedia exists in tension. I’m very wary of the idea of one man having so much editorial power, and wary of people who want to frame such centralized power as heroics. But I’m just as wary of those who would claim it’s all an evil conspiracy. I’d like to be questioning and curious rather than cynical and distrustful

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: When we upsample imaging artifacts end up mostly above what we can hear

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: When we downsample the unfiltered artifacts end up aliasing into the audible band

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So the trade offs are harder

author: ALXCPH
content: What’s your thought process behind, having “some aliasing” with 48k but not from 44.1?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Steeper filters, or lower cutoffs protect better against aliasing, but blur transients. Not always bad, but it changes things

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Filter affects the audible band less when going from 48k up

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Going from 96 to 192 for example is completely inaudible

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: 44.1 is the hardest up and down

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: For aggressive or highly transient material I will tend to leave some aliasing, and have less filter blurring (less steep/higher cutoff)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: For rounder and less transient  stuff like some folk or strings I would for steeper

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Get a good acoustic drum recording and listen to what it does to snare and hat transients

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Again not always bad, but it has a sound

author: masteredbyjack
content:
My above answer still applies to actual compression in general but just watched realized he was talking about the Pro L2 on that...I can't believe I'm going to contradict someone so many pay grades ahead of me but the attack and release on the Pro L2 are not really what they seem so I'm not sure what he is saying is actually correct. They don't work like a normal compressor does, and it's odd how the release characteristic sets in. The way he seems to have it dialed, in my understanding, isn't doing the bpm thing that I think he thinks it is (though of course this doesn't mean it doesn't sound good)

Someone posted the article deep diving into the Pro L2 thing on here before. If interested it is worth a read

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I think this is a great example of what @Nomograph Mastering spoke about on the live…his masters are clearly excellent and he is doing big time work.

But this doesn’t mean that he is sharing his process in a way that is actually useful to someone watching (see the above discussion regarding the bpm stuff).

I would say slapping an SSL channel on a master would be something I literally never do and would not advise being a first starting point for most people looking to learn (too colored).

However, I’m sure million dollar snare actually has a specific reason that he would use it for that particular Ali mix regardless of if he even really understands “why” he’s doing it. Or rather can articulate it deeply. And the results speak for themselves.

I think the takeaway is to put reps in and develop your intuition rather than some specific technical technique. And be open to new ideas (but also to rejecting them). Somewhere along the way a personal style and taste develop (I am still very much on this path)

author: Rollmottle
content:
this whole "dark art" trope is one of things I can't stand. I used to believe this. "I couldn't possibly do this, only these chin-scratching gurus know how!" 

i was getting a record i had made mastered at United here in town. i went in to visit the studio (wow) and to check out the mastering room while the ME had our shit up. he had started getting initial moves locked in and he called me over to the sweet spot and sat me down and showed me how to A/B one move vs. the other. i sat down and it all clicked. it was at that moment i said to myself "wait...i know how to do this lol." that's when all the mystery and artifice disappeared. and now it is one of my goals to demystify this shit. it's really nothing more than a different kind of listening.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Everything, there are people doing the exact opposite to me in all sorts of ways and winning bigger

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: This place is pro audio. You’re just gonna get laughed at. Don’t bother. I’m working on some “printed” examples of various power products I can send you

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Well, with my Mod hat on I have to say that no one will get laughed at here, regardless of the question. @Gerhard Westphalen can you give people a simple explanation of why most of this stuff is bogus, or unnecessary

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Except in some very specific cases, everything makes a difference at some level. Power cables, other power products, USB cables…

author: David Fuller
content:
Quoting myself here: 
> Electricity does matter. But the thing is, not one single piece of equipment out there runs on AC directly. It's all converted to DC. Nothing causes more distortion in AC than a bridge rectifier. Luckily, none of that matters, because damn near all the harmonics from it gets filtered out by the filter caps in the power supply. If it doesn't, it isn't a competent design.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Did a blink test by moving the unit to another room in the house and have someone else turn it on/off. I could still pick out which was which. This was with an ADI-2 so if you think it’s just an incompetent design then I doubt you’ll find competent ones…

author: CHCarrollMastering
content: My next question was usb and Ethernet (for audio) cables

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: I’m currently working on a machine learning algorithm to help analyze gear like this since your simple sweep type testing doesn’t show these hidden details. I’ll be gathering a lot of “data” in a few weeks (recording lots of audio through gear)

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: As far as I know those relate to noise and grounding. The data passing through it isn’t what matters

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: There’s one piece of gear I won’t name which sounded different when playing wav vs flac files (admitted by the manufacturer). Turned out the extra processing power used by the cpu on it to decode flac files would introduce noise into the analog circuitry. Was a case where wav sounded different from flac which any reasonable person would say is ridiculous. Was just a problem in the gear but at the end of the day all gear has these kinds of problems on some level

author: Rollmottle
content: How do you account for a change in the shape of the noise floor but it doesn't show up when measuring the noise floor? Sorry, that doesn't make sense. What is your device doing?

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: It's not really the noise floor itself but rather the low level detail of material being played through it. Noise floor itself looks the same but if you null things in a certain way then you can start to see patterns between having it on/off. It's dependent on the material being played which is why using ML is the only way I see to analyze it

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: There are weird edge cases where issues can modulate noise floor but it won’t show on typical fft

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But not what the average guy or girl needs to worry about

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Remember my chain has 0.0002% THD, the mix has like 5%

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Totally down to explore just want to make sure young cats don’t think this is where they should prioritize

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: I only have a general sense of what the device does. Somehow purposely introduces low frequency noise into the power line with the goal of masking the 60Hz harmonics. Changes performance of gear across the entire spectrum. Somehow the effects pass through the brick PS on the RME. I've measured the PS and there's no difference down to the level my oscilloscope can measure

author: Rollmottle
content: You designed a device to try to do this? What was your hypothesis? I'm just trying to understand.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: I didn't design it. It's a product I bought after hearing it at a couple of other studios and then demoing in my own

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I’m a strong believer in the “two wrongs Don’t make a right” school of audio - see Antelope clocks or adding tubes n transformers to fix digital harshness

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: That's exactly what I found. The typical REW measurement always shows the same noise floor but if I watch the RTA in REW I can see some sort of pattern

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Except that it lowers the noise! Makes things null to a lower level

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The only way it can survive filtering is by adding “jitter” to the fundamental or LF noise which informs my 2 wrongs comment

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: (working theory is that the box is introducing a 50Hz ish wandering noise or low level fundamental - the 555 being perfect for 50Hz (ish) but with essentially random timing/phase relative to the mains)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Could we split taste into two categories?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: 1) Inherent (like informed by your earlier life, the country records your mom loved etc)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: 2) Developed (As in your sense of what records should/could sound like - informed by the work, reps, current popular records)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Dude, you're Elon compared to me

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Definitely but what records should/could sound like I'd say falls largely into the inherent. For me the inherent was a decade of music lessons 5 days a week with a teacher pushing me through a music degree before I got to high school, playing in orchestras, school bands, jazz bands, rock bands... while the developed was mostly a conscious effort through years of daily ear training (EQing etc) plus thousands of hours developing gear and learning to hear the smallest details (how does this cap sound vs to these 10 others)

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: The biggest reason I don't really post any "how to's" with mastering is I can't teach taste and telling someone to be immersed in music for 20 years isn't helpful. @Nomograph Mastering I know you came from a less "rigorous" background in your youth so you could probably offer better advice on how someone can actively improve their taste

author: peterlabberton
content: @hebakadry this is totally anecdotal, but it’s seemed to me for a while like there are more prominent women in mastering than those who work as producers/mixers. You, Emily Lazar, Piper Payne come to mind—am I missing more non-male folks in the production mixing side, or am I right, and if so, why? Have always felt the male skew of the industry is particularly extreme and want to learn more about how to work to change it over time.

author: hebakadry
content: Not necessarily...as far as pop is concerned yes absolutely…way more men still producing and mixing…but as far as electronic music is concerned, a very large swath of that stuff is produced and mixed by the same women that make those records.    The modular and synth scene has seen a massive change…there are sooooo many women in modular producing their own records, repairing their own modules and doing it all from start to finish.  I think that is a massive advancement.  It’s better but I think it’s in other genres…not in the major label/pop scene.  Its improved significantly also from when I first started 20 years ago.

author: Iwan Morgan
content: I would say even in the past 5 years there were still adverts in sound on sound with women draped across synths, we only recently changed to Gearspace after I called them out and kept the pressure up.  There’s a long way to go.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: IME this problem tends to come up more from mixing engineers who have watched some YT telling them everything needs to be -14 rather than from the artist. More often than not my discussion with the artist is “why getting this track to -4 might not be a good idea”

author: hebakadry
content: Adding that a lot of the mixes we get are designed with a particular compression sweet spot which is normal for certain types of music…and they are usually nowhere near the -14LUFS range. My spiel is basically, this is a transient thing that will very likely change and it would be better to focus more on getting it to sound good today, tmrw or 20 years from now.  Good to be aware of it and also not to take it too literally.

author: hebakadry
content: I have had several instances where the label/artist asked to turn up & compress my master more in the context of a particular pop playlist where surrounding tracks were extremely crushed.  I wish we had tools from the DSPs to test how they work exactly. It's all approximation.

author: sethearnest
content:
On an iPhone -- Setttings --> Bluetooth --> [your device]  --> scroll down to accessibility --> scroll down to "Follow iPhone" and turn that nonsense off. 

At least this is how to do it on my phone and AirPods -- I'm presuming same for Beats. 

Sometimes you also have to turn off any "spatialize audio" per app while it's playing, e.g. start streaming a file from within your DB app and, while it's playing, swipe down on your screen and hold down on your ear buds volume section on the screen to get it to open into a new screen in which you can toggle some options.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Follow up question is if you had a program which could automatically find artifacts so that you know a file is bad before listening, how beneficial would that be?

author: Slow Hand
content: If it were 100% reliable it would probably be worth it's weight in gold.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Even if it weren’t and only caught, say, 50% of problems, that would already save you from listening through half the bad files

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Not at all suggesting it’s a replacement for QC

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Just a pre QC filter to help reject files

author: Slow Hand
content: Good point. At least it could flag something that's obviously messed up and let you skip to re-rendering before you do your QC.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I guess it could be a sub-routine that comes at the render stage. If the algorithm detects a click/pop/etc it would automatically re-render until it gets it right.

But perhaps I'm mistaking where these imperfections originate from.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: I haven’t had any artifacts in years. I’ve only had them from a bad update on ProL (may have been when L2 was released) but I almost never update software. I do still QC everything both just in case and since it’s one last opportunity to listen in case I have any doubts. Since I never have any artifacts, I’m curious what other people are QCing for

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Implementation would probably involve deep learning using many “samples” of artifacts to learn what is and isn’t an artifact. Could be tricky to get right but I think it’s possible

author: masteredbyjack
content: I suppose because I just want to know the render went correctly, yeah. And because if there ever was an artifact and I sent it, it would be terribly non professional

author: masteredbyjack

author: austenballard
content:
Can you say more about what the things are? Totally fine and I respect if you can't/don't want to for any reason. 

This intrigues me though, because I'm inclined to believe that there are things that we can perceive but not measure (yet) - either on account of confounding variables, inadequate measurement tools, or straight-up missing the point. Also, to circle back to my Core Audio question, there are all these black boxes that we have to work with constantly and just trust that they're doing what they say on the tin because "1 + 1 = 2" and "1 + -1 = 0"... but documentation is often scarce or obscured by marketing, and more importantly, anything made by a human being probably has flaws - certainly software does.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: But of course those people will then say that either my gear is broken or just because the computer can hear it doesn’t mean you can… They just want some kind of double blind study except I’ve found that doesn’t work for this kind of thing. I may write a blog post about it but essentially there are a number of factors which can throw off the blind test. Plenty of times I can’t do it and I know I can’t but when I get in the zone there’s no question and I don’t get any trials wrong. Next to impossible to get everything right for any kind of study which everyone would approve of

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Mainly relates to power things like I have a device I mentioned here a few weeks ago which all it does is plug into the wall and makes everything sound better. If this system works then it could be used for pretty much anything in audio which gets dismissed as snake oil

author: austenballard
content: The people clamoring for double-blind everything are usually the ones who wouldn't be able to explain experimental design to you if pressed. Especially the GS types. Adequate statistical analysis can glean useful data from just about any type of study provided the researchers' thumb isn't on the scale anywhere. If you think there's something there, keep testing til you find the variable or confound.

author: austenballard
content:
Yeah no, not everyone needs to do tech deep dives - but I do wish we had more reputable figures doing them for the benefit of the community at large. 

Bumblebee basically stopped after FL fanboys started sending him death threats (or so I understand), plus he has some serious health issues he's openly discussed that handicap his ability to do it. 

ASR is great sometimes but I think he might lean a little too far to the hyper-objective "I measured it at x therefore it's better." Plus his audience is largely people who will spend half their paycheck on an RCA cable.

Hugh Robjohns can only do so much, though some of his digressions in the SoS forum are very thorough, and keep things relevant to music-making.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Are we talking mixing or mastering? Because I think the approaches are likely different

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: In mastering I rarely use sidechain high passes, the exception being on acoustic/jazz stuff where I’m actually using the broadband compressor as a mid control device

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
interesting that you view them differently. How come? 

In my context its processing on the instrumental bus during the mix process, but i figured the mastering peeps know the most about this topic.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Way more latitude for pumping, vibe etc in mixing. Mastering at any kind of upper level is rarely that invasive, although it happens

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: There’s a very common misunderstanding that when you high pass the side chain that the bass doesn’t get compressed. It absolutely does- it’s a wideband compressor, when it moves everything is getting turned down. What you change when you high pass the sidechain is the control signal - the instructions to the compression on *when* to compress. So high passing means that the low end triggers the compressor less, but when the compressor reduces gain the low end is attenuated along with everything else

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: I’m in the very early stages of designing the “console” unit (not sure what to call it) which will have the 2 line amps, SPL, transformers and tube buffer. It’ll have 2 sets of I/O to sit at the beginning and end of everything else. Still not sure of the best order for things in it and the levels I should be planning to work with in it/interfacing with it

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: First, more generally still. In most of record making we are trying to position signals so that we stay well above the noise floor, and below the point where something in the chain clips undesireably

author: hyanrarvey
content: I try to move only forward never back

author: hyanrarvey
content: So i am never redoing gain staging

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: This is kind of a tricky puzzle but first some ways to look at it

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: My main concern is getting the level down part way through since my EQs wouldn’t have level control on them. I don’t really want to need additional level control after them but at the same time I want to be hitting them close to the +24 level. Seems like maybe I can drop level after them and then everything else after (including ADC) runs at the lower level

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Or drive up through the last transformers and get back to +24 if I want them in

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Noise is not all that scary, it *was* a big issue back in the day, but modern records are mostly pretty loud, and the kinds of records that need no noise like jazz samba or whatever should stay in the box

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I’ll respond to Qs later, writing something for everyone first

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So, to the real challenge. The analog color gear, the very reason we might wanna go out of the box at all

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Buy, clone/modify/take what I want from the design, sell original. I want the learning experience and 100 hours of being kept busy. Not the gear

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: With analog color pieces the sweetspot for a given piece on given track is often pretty small - some gear is better in that regard, some worse. You all know I’m a die hard for simplicity and this is one of the reasons - if I introduce a color piece I want to manage the level for that piece, and not go round in circles juggling 3 incompatible sweet spots

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Why do you want to hit the EQs so hard?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Don’t worry about noise

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: So you’d rather lower overall level instead of running partly at the higher level and then dropping down the 6dB?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Absolutely. We get to design the clean parts of the chain so that their noise is so low that we never have to think about it

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Wouldn’t it be better to just have a pad? Just trying to understand the reason for doing one over the other. Even if noise is negligible, one option must still be better than the other

content: Unnecessary, your color pieces will define the noise floor of the analog loop. Tube gear will be 20dB + above your line amps and EQ

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: That’s a good point but when we talk about comparing DACs and whatnot, isn’t it the extremely low level stuff that translates into the differences we hear? Doesn’t that translate through the increased noise floor from the “noisy” part of the loop? Seems like we should preserve as much of that starting right at the DAC

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Again, if I want low noise I stay in the box

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Even tube gear noise looks awful but it’s mostly LF where our ears are really not sensitive to it

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I certainly don't want to discourage anyone from learning about this stuff...I think the minimalism and thought that goes into mastering is great and can be worthwhile as a general approach!

And I really don't want mastering to be a black box thing at all. Knowledge is good. 

But I'm also wary of the responses of the type of @macca...(I say this in a kind way to challenge you)...you just assume that what Ruairi says is good and that you've learned something about mastering. Maybe. But also maybe you're a totally different ear than him, and a more aggressive approach suits you better!

I've always been a pretty minimal processor so I think his and my approach are sorta just fits from the get-go.

I really regard Ruairi very highly and have learned an immense amount from him...and the main thing is to trust your own taste and find out for yourself. So I'd challenge everyone on here to take the simple exercises and use it as a way to bring out your taste and point of view...and be very intentional about that. Don't just take his word for it, even though it's probably right most of the time.

author: austenballard
content: Just popping in to mention that there's a lot of research that's been done into selective attention particularly with regard to auditory processing. What @cian riordan  mentioned earlier, noticing things when you step away, is very much how the brain is wired to work. I can link Wikipedia articles if anyone is interested in diving in.

author: austenballard
content:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selective_auditory_attention
Overview of selective attention re: auditory processing. Describes a few of the major theories but a good chunk of the article is about disordered auditory processing, which isn't directly relevant here.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cocktail_party_effect
Noticing a salient signal against background noise. Highly relevant to what Cian was talking about earlier.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broadbent%27s_filter_model_of_attention
Broadbent's Filter Model of Attention, the first major model of attention that was proposed based on hearing tests.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attenuation_theory
Treisman's Attennuation Model, which builds on Broadbent's research and is regarded by a lot of people as probably the most realistic interpretation of attention.

content: Situations like that are tough bc expectations and reality are very separate and when you come in as the “fixer engineer” you multiply that expectation by like 10 times.  In a scenario like that I won’t commit to the whole record and I’ll just do 2 songs to see if I’m even the right engineer for them.  I don’t want to waste their time or mine.  If they still love the other crushed master, then there’s a confirmation there for them and we can walk away with minimal damage.  Also I would take my money upfront before I do anything.  Mastering work is never spec work.  And if they don’t want to pay upfront that’s a red flag and I can just walk away.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: This is a big topic, more than I have time to address today. But an impornant point - don't assume because I hit it around that level that you should. I reach for the Fearn in particular circumstances, very different to using it on a mic bus generally

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Set the attack to slowest

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Now print a recording of the chorus through the Fearn (no compression)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Then clip gain the source file up 1dB and print again (and after you capture clip gain the recorded file *down* 1dB)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Then you'll have 10 files, all around the same level that show you the color of what happens when you push the Fearn

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The sweetspot will be different depending on low end content etc

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: As you work with better mixers the REF is almost always very close to the released Master level

author: Slow Hand
content:
**Pro-tip to the Xfer OTT users:** If you Cmd+click on these green bars that are part of the threshold slider you can disable the upward expansion or the downwards compression on each band.

This will make it *far* less noisy and far easier to isolate the juiced-up sound of OTT that we love without so much crazy noise floor.

author: Slow Hand
content: It's not intuitively obvious that you can do this, so I suspect it's worth mentioning here for those who don't already know that you can do this.

author: JakeTB
content: Do you mean to say disabling specifically the high band is helpful in reducing the noise?

author: JakeTB
content: Also had no idea that we could disable bands in the XFer version- very cool

author: Slow Hand
content: Basically. Disabling the upwards expansion on *any* of the bands can do a lot to keep every bit of the noise floor from coming up, but still retain the absurd crushed-quality that we all like about OTT.

author: JakeTB
content: Gotcha! Thanks for clarifying

author: jonmatteson
content: you can also do this in the og ableton version by simply dragging down the expansion bars

author: Slow Hand
content: Funnily, I never use the Ableton version. I use the Xfer remake because of it's GUI and because I can transfer it to other DAWs.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Here's something I never hear anyone talk about

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: We all, every single one of us, have the exact same size bucket for low end and overall level

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The whole game in great records is sleight of hand

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Making things *seem* huge but somehow fitting them into the exact same size bucket we all have to work with

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So many mixes I work on and records I hear are people just trying to jam more in the bucket, more samples in parallel, more saturation, more level

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: And for the most part it's a failure

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The goal needs to not be filling every cubic inch of the bucket, but creating contrast

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: **Draw people into the Alice in Wonderland alternate reality of your record**

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: You get to define what big is, by placing something small next to it

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Would stonehenge be impressive in scale if we moved it to Manhattan?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: You get to define what close is by creating a sense of a back wall, or a horizon

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: All of my favorite records are sonic worlds with their own laws of physics - the artist and engineers get to define that

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: What's a mastering girl or guy to do with this information? Not that much! We don't really have control at all over these variables, and most of the records we love are not defined in the way that we think they are by the mastering

author: Zach Hughes
content: I idea of sound recordings being a finite container has helped me immensely, from production / arranging to mixing.

author: Zach Hughes
content: Lotta folks think doubling / tripling all their tracks will make their records sound huge. Then everything just gets tinier

content: There’s that, but also the fact that people have unsuccessfully tried to stuff “everything is big” productions and mixes into the same sized bucket billions of times now.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The records we tend to live and remember sonically are mostly cut from a different cloth

content: in a sentence: if everything is big and loud, nothing is

author: David Fuller
content: Something's gotta give somewhere

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But what I want to get into the public consciousness is that we don’t want things to BE huge, we want them to SEEM huge

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Spielberg doesn’t really want to kill all those men at the start of Saving Private Ryan, he just wants us to believe that it happened

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: It’s an important difference

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Chasing big is wrong, that’s easy and mostly won’t work

content: Sure, I get what you're getting at. Most guitar sounds that you think are huge are pretty small, the bass makes them sound pretty big

content: But tell that to someone who is starting out recording guitars and they want to capture the sound of their big ass amp

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: They think bigger is better

author: LAPhill
content: It's hard to get that point across to people until they have a decent amount of experience, methinks. As in, it's easier to show someone a better way once they admit to themselves that their big ass guitar and big ass drums and big ass bass aren't giving them what they want.

author: David Fuller
content: On a related note: the meaty bass is like, 70-100hz

author: David Fuller
content: below that is boom, mostly

author: David Fuller

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I think we can start with more careful language around productions, we should be thinking of it as an illusion and referring to it in that way

author: LAPhill
content: It's also easier at that point to separate out the instant gratification. Recording that guitar with pig-nose is going to be the best for the record, but is just not as satisfying to play on the way in if you don't know where it's headed.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: As opposed to some documentary style thing that is literal

author: Zach Hughes
content: how would you unpack the idea of the 'illusion' to a young artist who is making their first record?

author: LAPhill
content: Parallel to the illusion idea, is the idea of context. One of the most common things I see in my world is people using the same 3 chords with the same melodic structure as *insert Epic track here*. But if you JUST use the peak of the experience from a longer cue, you're missing the contrast as you say. Even within a production with contrast, your bass is going to hit harder if it's not consistent from beginning to end. Hence the drop.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: QC time over here but off the top of my head I would say that stepping back and perceiving the totality as much as possible

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: And less thinking in terms of things (bassman, supraphonic, Devil Loc) and more thinking in terms of constrasts, depth of field, experiences over time

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The great writers don't have different words to us

author: LAPhill
content: This is also why using ref mixes isn't very fruitful. You're comparing the contrast of your track to something else in a way no end listener ever will. Your quest for contrast needs to exist inside your own material.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Yep,  your own alternate reality

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Great comedy is such an example

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The same few words can have profoundly different impacts depending on where they are placed in the arc of a bit, or a set

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So often you’ll see young comics with a great line, but no concept of how it works in the whole

author: Slow Hand
content:
I would try to show them real examples, when possible.

I'll sometimes use the analogy of "stage makeup" to describe certain kinds of illusion in mixing. When you see stage actors up close after a show they have heavily-caked makeup, bags painted under their eyes, over-emphasized eyebrows and tons of blush. It's all so that the face can be read and easily perceived as "natural" by people in the audience who are viewing them from 100 ft away.

An analogous example in records would be something like Jimmy Page's guitar tracks. They were recorded on a 20-watt amp and when solo'ed in a mix they sound anemic and harsh. But that bite allows them to cut while the electric bass and the drums fill in the low-end. Then the listener's brain perceive's Jimmy's guitars as going very low, when they're, in fact, super thin.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Exhibit D in why screens are mostly the worst thing to happen to music

author: Slow Hand
content: This kind of arranging is a big part of what @oaklandmatt and Jon discussed in the March 7th episode when they spent 45 minutes discussing the new Skrillex records.

author: Deleted User
content:
I love the Alice in Wonderland expression. That’s what I try to chase in a record, for it to be its own world. 

The right mix can make the experience more immersive and believable like a good CGI and VFX would, but what goes in there, storyline/concepts, and the performance of actors and how director packages them is what makes them convincing to believe or stay.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Great. It doesn’t mean it has to be weird, it just means that in a record we can set the rules, and the expectations and the relative scales and intensities

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: OK, @spectrummasters I'm QCing and have a few mins to answer your questions as best I can. I'll try to format this to be somewhat readable

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Overall my masters are maybe 1 or 2 dB hotter than the ref mixes

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I guess one thing I can say is that working at a set level in the room matters for knowing where things are sitting relative to each other

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: From Spectrum *"I also wondered did you stay in the box for this one ?"*

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: This was definitely a challenge

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Honestly not really sure, I didn't get the files all at once, and there were some mix changes and replacements as we went. But overall I would say everthing I mastered was sent out the same day I worked on it, there was no time to sit and review

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The big thing with this record is that it really is the perfect example of what I've been talking about here this last while. Lana and Jack and the other Producers were very specific in what they crafted, it did not want or need to be turned into a slick pop banger

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: It's dark, moody, dynamic, distorted in places, sharp, blurry etc

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So my job was not to master it with a cookie cutter, center of the bell curve approach

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: It was to love it for what it is and frame that

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Minimize distractions, shape the extremes, sweat the details, enhance where I could

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But it is not a record for other engineers 🙂

author: Bonati12461
content: "Not a record for other engineers" - ha you don't hear that said enough. You're mastering for the artist in a suboordinate role, you're not just mastering to impress your audio buddies.

author: ALXCPH
content: Imagine a future where an AI is trained on engineers instead of the music, and is able to predict and make the moves they would have made in any context. You just get a drop-down menu and you can select the different ME style you want 🤓

author: ALXCPH
content:
A chess AI is able to analyse 1000s of games of a player and play the types of moves that player would make in different contexts. 

I also just saw a recent anti cheat AI for gaming that’s signing with all the major platforms. 

It is able to make biological signatures of how players play, so that if you are caught cheating and get banned, it is able to track you in other games even if you don’t cheat, because it knows how you move/play. 

Kinda scary 🤯

author: hebakadry
content: Music (for me is about community/culture across the world first and foremost).  I’m sure AI can eventually make really cool stuff and knock us all out of our jobs some day probably soon, but I firmly believe you cannot fully replace us with what is its to be part of a community and how that leads to incredible music because of shared experiences.  Even as engineers.

author: hebakadry
content: It’s the kind of music I always aspire to be part of. Whether it’s a Gamelan noise group in Indonesia or Detroit Techno.  Everything else is just facsimiles and that probably works for a lot of things I’m sure.  Will mastering disappear in a few years…maybe…I hope not.  We might still be around but it could be a rarity.  If that happens, it happens there’s no stopping it.

author: ALXCPH
content:
I see a future(many years out still), where creation has evolved into thought proceses instead of skill sets. Collaboration Will still exist because humans have a need for other humans. 

Kind of like mid journey. Creatives Will just put words to their thoughts and make a prompt which is met by an AI. 

By then art will have de comoditized itself through its democritization.  So the need for “competitiveness” and “comparativeness” become obsolete so the need for “experienced ears” won’t exist. Art will have returned to its original form of honest thought experiments, with no need for expertise but collaboration for the sake of relations instead of wisdom. 

👽

author: ALXCPH
content: But we’ll probably be living in a post economic world by then since most labour will have been replaced by robots 🤖 so no need to worry 😄

author: popaganda.

author: ALXCPH
content:
The post is mostly tongue in cheek 😉

But to try and define what art in its purest form is, that is what my brain comes up with 😇

author: CK
content: I find mastering to be so incredibly painful.

author: CK
content: Especially mastering my own stuff.  Not only have I lost perspective on it at this point, my setup does not allow me to hear it with more clarity than what I mixed it at.

author: CK
content: My mixes come out at -9rms and -9lufs on average.  So I can hit some standard volumes, but that final polish, I have zero desire to try to do this again myself.

author: CK
content: Anyways, I am ALWAYS going to put Mastering into my quote from now on, and I will always hire one of you. I do not know how you do what you do so well. Maybe one day I will. author: Nomograph Mastering
content: - the reality is that most projects are cut and pressed with all in deals and the brokers use contract cutters who are just cranking out sides all day. No test cuts, no time for optimization just getting through the work

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: It’s likely that your audio is going to a broker/all in deal (most project do. So what can you do to optimize?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Honestly IME if you get a bad cut then different files will make very little difference. Stuff like excessive low pass filtering is a bummer

author: Jodonny
content: What's everyone's thoughts on summing bass frequencies to mono and the best tool/process to do it?

author: Jodonny
content: I work a lot with stereo synth basses in Ableton, and putting a Utility on the track or bass bus that with the Bass Mono engaged is "easy" but is that really causing phase issues? I can't find info on what it's actually doing. Is the Nugen Monofilter a better option?

author: Jodonny
content: Does everyone do it? Mastering or Mixing? In my tests, Skrillex has everything below 130 hz 100% mono on his latest record, but the low mids are suuuuuuuper wide and out of phase at times

author: ALXCPH
content: This is a great tool for it https://www.toneprojects.com/basslane-pro.html

author: ALXCPH
content: But really consider why you want to mono your lowend and to what extent, you can end up doing more harm than good, if you are just defaulting to it without knowing why you are doing it

author: ALXCPH
content: If you arent having any aparent issues then why do it

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But when you hear it in a great room it’s almost always worse

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But most people have never actually heard the width and texture of low end in a great rooms

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I was all about MS too until I could really hear the damage it does

author: ALXCPH
content: I Think its still noticable in less then ideal listening situations, because it still affects the stuff above.

author: ALXCPH
content: I pretty much never mess with the width of lowend unless there is something really problematic. Like you Said yourself, it is rarely better.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Agree, you can hear the negatives above, but I’m saying the differences down low that you don’t hear are actually lovely and musical and useful

author: Rollmottle
content: otherwise not a move i make

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Mono bass often sounds totally 2 dimensional relative to unfucked with

author: Jodonny
content: So interesting. So do you guys think the EDM guys just do it out of habit or is it actually useful for live mono PA's like they talk about?

author: ALXCPH
content: I Think its a youtube/GS thing that just caught on and became an easy thing to repeat to Sound like you know what you are doing

author: ALXCPH

author: ALXCPH

author: masteredbyjack
content:
You know, I actually use it sometimes but only for very specific things, if I want certain wide vocals to sit a certain way, to let more of a certain range be more focused on the center, etc. always very small moves, but it does work sometimes for me well

As with everything, it’s all trade offs

author: Rollmottle
content: is raising or lowering the sides or center technically M/S? then yes, i do that when needed. if by M/S we mean trick widening and whatever else other horseshit is out there, then no, i don't do that.

author: masteredbyjack
content: Mostly I’m just doing a very very tiny and broad cut at some range in the sides only! I have yet to use any widening ever. Haven’t yet just raised one or the other, but I should keep that in mind! Thanks for sharing that

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: No, just a straight level shift of M or S doesn’t have a downside to me

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: S down more often than up being the contrarian that I am

author: stefanmacc
content: I’ve always “heard” that since the PA sums to mono for the sub you risk phasing out there. And that’s why it’s become a thing in edm . Because the mix IS the show. But other than that I don’t see a point

author: Edward Rivera
content: My live friend says that's all but true these days. He mixes in stereo for gigs

author: stefanmacc
content: Yes I believe most all gigs are in stereo haha. This wouldn’t really apply to festivals or places with dedicated FOH . This is more so night clubs with a built in PA and CDjs I’m referring to . Where the subs are in mono.

author: stefanmacc
content: This isn’t really for mastering talk but I know Dave rat who mixes for RHCP will put his subs in stereo and pan kick and bass to opposite sides of whatever arena they are in. That way he avoids cancellations. But most live setups I’ve seen or mixed on are single summed mono sub sends….

author: Nils
content: i think its great to put certain frequencies to the side or mid

author: Nils
content: M/S is really important in my opinion i mean your options are endless you can compress the mid signal more than the side signal or you can boost frequencies only on the side

author: David Fuller
content: Yes, but let's step back for a second and think about how that will affect how the mid and sides sum

author: Will Melones
content: It’s the stuff that overlaps mid and side that gets extra weird. In mixing, if you want it wider without pulling those tracks apart, you can pan wider or turn up the hard-panned tracks to avoid the messy phase math

author: outofmana

content: I really, really love this Discord and the general attitude/collective knowledge and experience of you folks.

author: cian riordan
content: I found myself swimming in ego when I first started (mostly my own.) Propped myself up as someone who had all the answers, looked down on everyone else’s work. I was the best. Having a mentor like Eric was humbling in that regard. Not only was I not in fact the best, it didn’t take me long to realize that he wasn’t either… and he knew it. Seeing him traverse the music industry, doing the best job possible, while being kind and fair to people, understanding artist intent and vision, and being absolutely honest about his own shortcomings — you couldn’t pay enough money for that kind of masterclass. I’m very lucky to have been exposed to that, not just as a recording engineer, but as a human being.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Building better humans one record at a time

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: It’s the real value of what I’ve often called “the stone we sharpen ourselves on”

author: Deleted User
content:
On this topic- people say “there’s no tough love in this industry. If you do something wrong, or something they don’t like- they won’t tell you. They will be kind to you as best as they can, and never call you back”

I think there have been a few moments where I clearly fucked up and no one told me a thing because they don’t want to give unsolicited advice or look like an asshole. It’s fair and probably a reasonable thing to do in a lot of cases, but I think some hard truths with good intention and empathy can really go a long way. Which is why I appreciate people who keep me in check and give me honest truth or opinion. 

“the truth will set you free. but first, it will piss you off”

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: A good question would be “what does aliasing sound like?”

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Once you have the answer to that the next question is “Am I likely to hear that aliasing character over/through the mostly noise based sound of a snare”

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So I guess I am saying break it into chunks - identify what the “problem” sounds like, identify the upsides of the “fix” and identify the downsides of the fix. Once you have a handle on those separate things you can make intelligent case by case choices fast

As someone who *does* understand what's happening technically a lot of what I see written online is just wrong, or at least focussed on the wrong aspects.  The loudest voices tend to be the -14 crowd like Ian Shepherd who clearly can't see the forest for the trees.

author: Jodonny
content:
100%, which is why I’m thankful for this Discord, podcasts and people like yourself - where I can a variety of opinions of people who actually do work. That’s one of the things about Dan, he’s very interesting from a scientific standpoint, but doesn’t actually have a lot of real world professional experience, so it’s hard to trust his opinion when he’s high passing low end in masters and whatnot. 
And like you said, the reality is that we all do things different, no matter how successful/big people are, and all of us do “wrong” things. I’m a firm believer in focusing on the “art” of producing/mixing/mastering until you reach a technical problem, such as CPU issues, then learn as much as you can. Newfangled Saturator is an example of a high-cpu setting on by default (problem), that has led me to try to get real-world professional opinions/solutions, so I can make up my own mind on whether it’s useful.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Good luck, just be careful of the wisdom of the crowd here

author: Jodonny
content: https://youtu.be/xmEf1Uejn8w?t=41

author: Jodonny
content: It sounds wild on paper, but it's about doing something subtle multiple times in a row. Say you have a bass loop that last 10 seconds and at 3 and 8 seconds you have a peak, you lightly control that, now it's more even, but now you have a peak at 2 and 5 seconds, you control those lightly, and progressively you have a smoother sound rather than one compressor going hard and even sometimes distorting a sound. If you think that way about mixing that way from the ground up, it'll make sure your main busses aren't working that hard.

author: Jodonny
content: I'll almost never add an l1 to something where I see it constantly triggering, that's a lot. I use it the top peak control. Puts vocals, and vocal groups in your face and smooth. Sounds way better than Rvox IMHO

author: Iwan Morgan
content: I'm sure @Nomograph Mastering will have someting to say on this but in my partial dalliances with radio playlisting there are a lot of variables.  Some of my records get played on different BBC stations: 6Music, Radio Wales, Radio Cymru and BBC Radio 3.  Each station sounds different, so when one of the songs was playlisted on 6Music it also got played on the other stations and consequently sounded all over the shop.  I don't think they use Optimod procesing anymore but there is an ingest process which 6 music use and each file gets normalised to BBC Scale 6.  After this each DJ has has control over the volume level, which means they can push into the compressor.  This is a big sound for some DJs.  So I have no answers really apart from trying to be a little bit Zen about it.  It will sound different, but quite often a demo recorded for a late night Radio Cymru show will sound louder.  Dynamics, and micro dynamics win on radio which is why Arcade Fire's second record always sounded small to me on radio even with Spike Stent mixing some of the songs. (Too many overdubs)

author: Iwan Morgan
content: I did capture 25 mins of a 6 music show a few years ago and then lined up the commercial mixes of each track below so that I could A/B.  I'll have to dig it out and see whether I can come to any useful conclusions

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So, first things first

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: National broadcasters are generally a little less subject to these pressures but not by much. And of course a classical station may opt out of that competition almost completely

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Ok, so what is the actual processing?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: There have for a long time been two market leaders in the space, although there have been and continue to be others. Telos have their Omnia series of hardware processors and Orban have the very famous Optimod series.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Now to 3) Which is to deal with very varied input signals

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The system needs to account for very varied inputs and meet our criteria 1 and 2 while avoiding listeners having to turn things up and down

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: It’s got to work in the car, in a hair salon, on a building site etc

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So, where does good sound come into it? It’s lowest on the list for sure

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Now to what the actual processing is doing, it’s super intense and honestly amazing that anything survives at all

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Each station will have presets and their recipe is an important part of their offering

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Lastly, I don’t think radio actually sounds very good but there’s two reasons that I suspect we tend to think that it does

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: 2) Broadcast processing has generally and historically done “nice” things to older music from the 40s through maybe the early 80s

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: It makes it sound more exciting and finished

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So here’s a test I would have everyone who is interested do. Get yourself a decent receiver (probably $50 on a local used website) and connect it in the studio and listen to what’s really going on

content: Just bringing up the sides can hug the vocal, depending on the arrangement

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Often it's not the actual volume of a vocal that's the issue, it's the character. Ugly inharmonic stuff

author: Rollmottle
content: those ringy gnarly resonances can really uglify the vocal and draw unwanted focus to the wrong parts of the vox regardless of overall vocal mix volume.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Yep, and that stuff bugs the shit out of me

author: shaunobi
content: @Edsel Holden the best splitter algo right now (or as of a month ago at least) is Demucs from Facebook. It’s complicated; I host it myself in a Docker container. Uses a trained AI network to pull audio out.

author: shaunobi
content: I’ve used it quite a bit and it does work better than most. My first thought here, and this is highly experimental, would be to split out the vocal. I’d then run that back with the main vox and polarity invert it and bring it in enough to juuuust bring it down in the stereo mix to get where you want to go.

author: shaunobi
content: Or, just throw all four stereo faders up and rebalance a couple dB off and be done. My way is tomfoolery due to the fact that don’t think splitters will null when recombined… and I’m guessing this might have fewer artifacts

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: When you get an acapella file where there's hiss or other noise when there isn't singing do you clean that up so that it's completely silent or leave as is?

author: shaunobi
content: I almost never master stuff, but I'd personally just reduce between the hiss. Taking it out almost always sounds weird to my ears. "Here's a room! oh here's no room it's digital silence! oh here it is again!"

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I’ve done both - leave alone and reduce, never silence completely

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: I've always left it in but if the full mix has noise I'll usually play with the fades at the beginning/end to get the noise as hidden as possible so not sure if that should be my responsibility with acapellas as well when sometimes most of the file is hiss

author: shaunobi
content: ah got it. Yeah - I'd probably reduce but I always find it weird to hear hiss my ears "know" should be there all the time. And truthfully it can sometimes sound sort of cool.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: 1) I wouldn’t assume you can swap the masters later, some distributors don’t allow it. Of course you can release again but then you lose play count

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: 2) If at all possible get refs of the whole project when you are doing the early tracks. Even early stage roughs will give you a sense of the context of the whole project

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: 5) Think connection rather than perfection - how inconsistent does something need to be before it breaks connection? If it’s great then it needs to be pretty messed up, if it’s bad they were never connected anyway

In fact, I keep little micparts kits and sub $100 Focusrite interfaces I get used off CL and anybody who can scrape up $300 I just build a setup with them and diy acoustic treatment. I’m thinking along the lines of… “anything above a threshold gets brought down the same amount”…not “bring all samples down to a given threshold” if that makes sense. It’s clip gain essentially

Of course the edges of where it crosses over/etc make a difference

This is just something I’m mulling over, I’m not sure it has any application in real world

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: When we change the shape of a waveform we distort it. If it’s 3 samples you won’t hear it but if it’s longer section you will

author: Rob Domos
content: There’s a study where people were given story problems, like verbal escape rooms, and when the story problem was delivered in first person, ie. “You’re stuck in this room” people were generally terrible at solving it. When the story problem was delivered in third person, ie. “jimmy is stuck in this room” they solved it pretty quickly. I think of this often and wonder how I could harness this knowledge to shift my perspective so I always act as if I was jimmy

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: I’m not saying this is a thing but it could be and not for the reasons you think. CPU itself and everything going on in your computer will be exactly the same no matter what. Digital stuff is impossible to be any different (unless you get dropouts…). What is different is the amount of electrical noise going on. Both radiated in the air and on the power line. Computer does more crunching, it uses more power and makes more noise. That noise can affect your audio gear. Through the power line, into things like PCIe audio interfaces, and on things like USB. There are ways to work around this. If this is really happening on your system then it’s something you should fix

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Not to mention fan noise. When your fans ramp up you’re changing the noise floor of your room

author: cian riordan
content: I can understand building a vocabulary of acoustics, speakers, etc while shuffling between different rooms of various states, but I for the life of me can't really wrap my head around how you could make sense of DACs in this situation. The differences between these boxes are SO suble and minute, and barely perceivable in environments that you are intimately familiar with... how you could do it while tuning rooms just doesn't align with what I know about what humans can percieve (not to mention confirmational bias).

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But not everything that can be perceived matters

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So part of it is just mastering brain

author: cian riordan
content: Perhaps. But critical listening is critical listening?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The thing with going from room to room was that there were always some elements carried over, my DAC, PMC models I knew inside out

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: There’s things that emerge over time when you’re not actually looking for them

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I’m not attached to it, and honestly that kind of listening skill is basically useless

author: cian riordan
content: But I disagree! I think having these listening skills actually helps you figure out what is A) A discernable difference B) A useful difference and C) a valuable investment of money and resources.

author: cian riordan
content: Most people are just jumping to C.

author: cian riordan
content: I was lucky to have had a science background, paired with years of setting up these test with EV, to come to my own conclusions around the smoke and mirrors in the 'Mixdown Industrial Complex'.

author: cian riordan
content: I'm fully open to things sounding different; for my brain not being tuned into subtle differences. I'm just not open to folks who've done very little testing (not @Nomograph Mastering) going on about things I've heard with my own two ears to not be true.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I guess I’m say that there’s a world where people claim these differences and use their perception (real or not) of it to elevate themselves

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: That’s not what I want to be known for, perceiving tiny details like that

author: cian riordan
content: Actual value there. Greg Wells is a great example.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Feeling the song is where I can make a difference

author: cian riordan
content: He claimed x,y,z about the Antelope clock back in the day -- saying it was the difference between mono or stereo or some bullshit -- and we did a serious test over the course of days to figure out if there was a perceivable difference (we couldnt)... but we came away with the mentality that if a piece of kit gives you the confidence to do better work, then it's worth every penny.

author: cian riordan
content: Haha, bad example. But also revealing. We're all human. Conformational bias is very real.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The trick is genuine agnosticism
