author: Rollmottle
content:
Great question.

For me, I don’t know if it was more aptitude for mastering per se, but more about realizing that the way in which I’ve listened to records for as long as I can remember, was what mastering actually was. As much as people would have me believe, mastering wasn’t processing stuff with esoteric analog gear in an ivory tower and then descending from on high to bestow one’s genius onto the world. It was listening deeply and appreciating and loving a record for what it is. I love that records can be their own little worlds with their own language and idiosyncrasies. Being in a position to help reveal and enhance a world that somebody is trying to bring to life is at the nexus of where I think all of my musical skillsets, taste, and wiring of my brain are most valuable to other people. Having been an artist on the other side of it, I know what it’s like to pour blood sweat and tears into a record only to have a bummer of an experience at the last step. And so I am also motivated by providing an experience that stokes people out, rather than create more uncertainty. 

Interested to hear other people's takes.

author: JakeTB
content:
Okay first technical question of this ME journey- 
If you upsample a recording 
(48->96 in this case) for a processing move, how often do you downsample it back for delivery?

In this context, it’s an indie artist and streaming-only release.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Good practice because upsampled content is not accepted at labels

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Not sure there is much advantage to be gained from upsampling to 96k generally though, if you do upsampling you’ll want to go higher, and then you need a solid understanding of filtering etc to be able to gain more than you lose

author: Rollmottle
content: if a label delivers something at 96/24 are they intending it to stay there or they are going to do with it what they will? i'm dealing directly with artists and mixers mostly so i try to give them what will reliably work in the digital distros and come out the other end as expected.

content: But my preference is not to manage it, even if I could get $$$ for it. I do the best I can, then I hand it off, then someone elevates it further, and we've all done the best we can, and the artist releases it, and with hindsight we learn from it.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Some ideas in no particular order

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: - Try to do as little as possible processing wise to get the desired result

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: - if you hit a wall in mastering step back and consider what might need to change in the mix

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: - We’ve debated the usefulness of referencing here and there are different takes but constant comparison seems to undermine connection to the work. So try to ring fence time spent listening to references into useful chunks

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Search for me talking about a high pass 400 Hz filter

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I did a whole riff once on my theory of the 3 sizes of a mix - phone (nothing below say 300), small speaker Alexa etc  (nothing below 80) and then full range (club/good car/headphones)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: That’s it. IIRC it goes on for a while and I make a case against specific janky (one particular small speaker) and a case for generalizable janky (using filters on your full range speakers)

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Of course! Regarding RX…I was just referring to using the spectral repair replace with either not a big enough box, or sometimes on lower frequencies (say you are trying to remove someone hitting a mic stand or whatever which is lower than the mouth clicks in the spectrum)…I’ve found that it can give odd artifacts. Often just upping the numbers of bands (I like to think of them as buckets after I heard Ruairi mention that) can do it, sometimes it just doesn’t work.

It’s just a situation where you have to listen, it’s usually obvious on the actual spectral view but like @Rollmottle it can be finicky sometimes.

I avoided it in the vid because it’s a fairly rare problem that mostly, if not exclusively applies to treating an entire mix with full spectrum audio! And honestly not a big deal, just something I’ve found can happen on occasion

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: But you're right that it would no longer null.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: Even two bounces of the exact same mix- if there are any free-running LFOs that aren't synced to the session transport (e.g. most modulation in most reverbs/choruses), the spatial effects will be slightly different, and won't null.

author: Slow Hand

I'll push back on the idea that Youtube is a poor place for nuanced educational content. I think it's one of the best resources for such things and is very much what you choose to make of it.

The truly "nutritious" content may not be the first result that appears (or the second or third), but it doesn't take too much effort to find the gold if you've got a discerning eye for such things.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Haven’t watched this vid (or any of his in awhile), when I was building my studio I watched some. They’re not really for me, a lot of things I’ve seen him do I simply creatively dislike from a sonic perspective. 

But I can’t hate on him for trying — I think it’s cool when people put themselves out there. And like many have said, he does actually do real work with legit artists. So good on him for trying to push some sort of conversation about mastering!

Now…would I personally approach the mastering discussion this way? No. That’s why I’m on here and in between my speakers, but I’d say he probably does more good than harm

author: masteredbyjack
content:
And to @Slow Hand point, YouTube really does have a treasure trove of info if you are willing to cherry pick some stuff and look into longer form things (the Ruairi and Dale vid for instance, and there is a 3 hour workshop of Dale going over mastering basics)

Sure, the internet often brings out the lowest common denominator but basically all of human knowledge is right at our fingertips tips too…so…sorta up to us to use it how we want

Let’s say someone has a binary answer in their head to a problem that would be better served without a clear answer. Ie. Louder is better, cleaner is better, mastering is nudging your mix towards the sonic middle, or whatever other half baked answer that lacks nuance. We question those, and we acclimate ourselves to engaging with paradox, and we’re all the better for it

content: I would maybe parse a difference between "they're right, period" and "it's their right to be the ultimate decision maker, period". Can be as simple as asking a few questions to open someone's mind to new ideas or approaches, doesn't have to be a lecture or an argument, doesn't have to be the producer/engineer/mixer taking control of the vision.

author: Slow Hand
content:
That's the one. I thought this was funny because the *Inflator* manual describes it's algorithm as such:

> The Inflator process functions by changing the relative probability of samples in the programme material such that there is a greater probability of larger values than the original signal. The Inflator does not employ signal compression, so there is no ‘pumping’, dynamic level change, loss of presence or flattening of percussive attacks. The full dynamic information of the music content is largely preserved despite the increase in average modulation density.

It goes on for two more paragraphs with this frothy nonsense.

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: Edsel Holden
content:
I think, for me or anyone, separating the idea of a "home run" master not getting the big playlists or commercial success is a hard pill to swallow, but an important one.

I want to believe that a home run is commercial success and that I can really affect that (i cant) but I want to believe that bc I truly do actually really care about this music and those that make it and I want them to "win" since we are tribe mates

But Roll is right on with the " the rest is out of my control." - and it's becoming clearer to me now that my ego is why I said *sometimes* in my earlier message.. because a home run master is not necessarily a guarantee for commercial success. But the home run is actually the "love of the thing it is back onto the song and they can cross the finish line with renewed confidence about intention and execution"

I hope you fookers are follwing me

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Two scenarios

1) The mix is jank, you go to V5 on the master, the artist just accepts rather than loves but it goes on to get 400M streams 

2) You connect to the song immediately, the mix is killer, you take it to the next level and the artist cries. But it gets 1000 streams

content:
Yes and a few reasons why.

Firstly, I just didn’t have the time anymore to real time bounce - especially when it came to multiple deliverables (Main, ACA, INST, TV, Clean, etc).

And Secondly going out and back in opens more opportunity for unintended changes to happen to the master, like LR Balance or dropped samples - you have to watch for that stuff like a hawk - so QC time increases as well keeping an eye out. More time spent bouncing and QCing, means less time available for more work and even less personal time.

Thirdly, I learned pretty quickly that people really love their mixes and the less I do to a track and the more I get out of the way to finish it, the happier everyone is. Having “fun” with gear (to me) was just me putting myself/ego into the equation and truthfully I just needed to get out of the way.

Fitter, Happier, More Productive.

But their drummer had interned at a studio in 2008 or something and just *knew* it had to be done that way. I was pretty bummed, but looking back, even if I’d done it, the whole process would have been a colossal pain in the ass and the record would probably have sucked. Gear obsession often has a dogma attached to it that completely ignores the actual music.

author: Nicky Howard
content:
Hi all 👋

First time posting! I've had a catch-up with some of the convos on the thread. The info being provided is pure gold (some the comedy variety). It's refreshing to hear open & interesting discussions on mastering rather than the usual shouty forum stuff.

There are nuggets given away kindly and freely that took me years of trail, error, and utter balls ups to come to the same place. 👌

On the analogue vs. digital thing, I agree it's done to death.

I went ITB a few years back, for one important reason, recalls. If you're a ME without a team, recalls are on you. Any time or place.

I've had projects signed off, and the mix changes hours before release (seems to happen more on bigger projects, with majors). 

One of these I was away. As my laptop mirrors my studio, I was able to have new masters printed, QCd, and back in under 30. It built trust and led to more work. 
If, instead, I'd have said;

"I need a week to fire up my tubes, I'm on holiday," 

Game Over. Man. Game Over.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I will often get the note “low end sounds huge! What did you do?” And the answer is that I cut half a dB at 3k

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: If you want huge low end in a mix or master try focusing your attention on  1500 to 6000 Hz. That whole area is the driver of how we perceive everything else

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Even with very amateur mixes I’m often leaving sub 150 Hz relatively untouched and biasing perception using the mid range

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: TLDR - if there’s too much of any band between 1500 and 6000 you won’t be able to perceive the rest of the frequency range correctly - it “blinds” us

author: Rollmottle
content:
I am not Ruairi but here's what I'd say to the OG question:

1. Don't try and out move what you can't hear. Never going to end well. There is no general rule sub 30hz so don't try and preemptively deal with something if you're not even sure it's an issue.
2. If you do need to deal with a low end issue, deal with it at the source, instead of the 2-mix if you can.
3. If you're dealing with it at the 2-mix level, gentle shelves will do less harm than steep cuts.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Here we see a simple 12dB/Oct high pass filter “throwing away” low frequency energy before measurement calculation. We can see that 60 Hz is only 3dB down, so energy levels there will matter more than down at 20 Hz (which is more like 13 dB down)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Where 30 Hz needs to sit relative to the track will vary enormously by genre, it definitely is not a case of more is better every time. Musically a lot of tracks can be weighed down by too much information down there

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: For me even my very basic understanding of how human hearing works allows me to ignore endless bullshit and what analyzers are telling me to focus on results

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Do you find it actual helps in arranging/mixing?

author: LAPhill
content: As I think about it, it might be more related to the harmonic series, but yes. Because I'm more likely to fix frequency buildup through arrangement, reducing what's happening in the bucket below is reducing the unpleasant overtones in the area where there's masking.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Such a perfect example of what I’m getting at. Just a basic understanding of two seemingly unrelated areas - harmonics and masking (auditory perception)  when added together give you the basis for better decision making. No need to reach for trackspacer (spits at ground), no hunting around for silver bullets. You understand the fundamentals so you can solve the problem on a more fundamental level

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I’ve never had any need of or use for automatic level matching of any kind - levels are kind of our thing as engineers. I level match fast by ear (LUFS is not accurate enough anyhow) and just make a call

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I’ve done this for coming up on 25 years using two faders in a DAW

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: One thing I guess we should say is that earlier in your engineering journey it can pay to be more fastidious with level matching. It’s so easy to get carried away with louder/more compressed/wider/more saturated

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Once you’ve made all those mistakes 1000 times avoiding them becomes a little easier

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But in the early years being honest with yourself via level matching helps refine the work

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: (Within reason! I wouldn’t be level matching every decision in a mix for example, you gotta have some forward motion)

author: Iwan Morgan
content: I worked on a few records with John Dent about 10 years ago and he kept saying “gain changes everything” and I think about that everyday. It’s had a profound effect on me that’s hard to quantify. His setup was so bespoke but the philosophy was that gain comes from all the small moves and amounts to the big wins when all the small things came together. He named his studio Loud Mastering and it’s still going, mastering PJ Harvey etc but unfortunately he passed away a few years ago.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Ah, when we say level matching here we mean comparing two things (any two things) at the same apparent volume, *not* turning things up until they match commercial releases

author: Edsel Holden
content:
I see stuff like this a lot and to be totally honest I ignore it, assuming the song sounds like a thought out idea and not "broken" - how's it sound ? Oddly dark and like something went wrong, or does it sound "fine" & it just looks different compared to "normal" mixes ? 

If the latter, I would assume intent and creative direction before I assumed something went wrong with the bounce..

author: Rollmottle
content: From an artist perspective, it's the world I and my friends have lived in since the early 2000's. It's just dudes releasing their and their friends' shit. Which is cool, because it ain't about money, it's just about releasing tunes. But also, since it's not about money, there is no money. The audience for that stuff is other dudes who release their and their friends' shit and bedroom DJ's who release a steady stream of mixes into the ether. It's just a tiny, money-less sub-scene of a much bigger world. It's not where the opportunity is (both from an artist and engineering perspective) if you're trying to do this for a living.

Practically I'm not saying it makes sense for most in the music industry and I imagine the higher up you go the less feasible it'd be

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The power to stop the line is great way to engender shared responsibility and ownership of the product, you’re but a drone in sector 7G you are a partner in the manufacturing process

author: Berlin

author: Berlin
content: With them, I oblidge, the sound is negligable if not completely unnoticeable, one time completely nulled out...

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I have no ill will for someone who brings mix brain, and understand why they might. Just wondering about actual useful strategies

author: Berlin
content: So I hit them with v2.. and they always reply enthusiastically "That's it! Nailed it! So much better!!"

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: They are almost always EQing their speakers in this case, but unless it actually breaks things I don't push back

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I very much want to be the "Yes, and" collaborator, but if I know we're headed for the collective weeds then I'm obliged to steer things somewhat

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Also there's a big difference between someone like Rostam who had me doing vocal ups on half a word on the Carly record (but has great ears and track record) vs someone who is just getting their sea legs

author: Berlin
content: That being said, I think the track sounds great already, and have told them so to hopefully get it over the line with enthusiasm.

author: cian riordan
content: The only parallel I have is people bringing 'producer-brain' to the mix process. And as much hassle as it can be, I will usually just inhale my despair and execute it. Am I going to spend the time to lecture them on what part of the process we're locked into? No.

author: cian riordan
content: The game is to get the ball down the field and into the goal. If someone passes to you, do you let them know that they should've passed to another person first, then pass back to you right before the goal?

author: cian riordan
content: No, you point yourself in the right direction and run.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: There's treacherous water between projecting confidence "Hey I think it's good and you should too becuase I've done some stuff" - using their trust in you to bring it home and then just being a past it douche phoning it in

author: cian riordan
content: I used to try and be the educator; try and let people know that this isn't really part of the process we're executing right now. But all of the roles are getting more and more jumbled these days -- producer, mixer, master-er. You have to be able to accomodate asks from all walks.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Yeah, def not on the education train

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I think I'm decent at handling, I was more asking for approaches to guide things without educating or pushing back

author: cian riordan

content: But now, with the tools ME's have...

author: Edsel Holden
content:
Very interesting - I just got something kicked back for "abrupt ending" and the player link they sent over was Disco.. 

I have never had something kick back for abrupt ending ?

Got about 200 ms silence after the end... they don't want it faded if they can avoid it.

What would you all do? I don't have much experience with things getting "kicked back"

I am going to add a small (micro) fade and re-send, but curious how others would handle !

author: Iwan Morgan
content: It’s a difficult one @Edsel Holden i’d probably doe exactly what you intend to do. In my case the band wanted one track to crossfade across the intro of another. It’s an indie rock thing with intro, reprise and outro themes reocurring throughout, artisticaly it is absolutely the right thing for the band to want to do, but it is a shame that the tech finds it really difficult to match their vision.

author: Edsel Holden
content: Oh yeah, those kinds of things always get tricky, this is why CD's are rad still (well, and other reasons)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: @Karim @eschirtz What's the latest state of play with Lossless playback in the event of a poor connection. Is it still automatically switching to lossy?

author: eschirtz
content:
If you have the lossless switch enabled, it’ll always be lossless. 

We do try and show a little message if we detect the internet is slow to let the user know they can switch the quality to adaptive. But we never auto-switch to adaptive. It’ll always be lossless.

author: thegreatcarsoni
content: That “update” button is so sexy. It calls to me, and whispers sweet nothings. I even felt compelled to update firmware for my router. But then I stopped myself and DIDNT. It’s really critical. And it helps to get in the habit of reviewing change logs, and going in with a goal in mind: “did they fix X thing that’s a pain point? Does it add Y functionality I need? Does it do this without widely reported failure?” And over time I’ve found MOST updates are useless for me or at best aesthetic

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Ok, let’s say we have a compressor with a 10dB threshold

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Once it exceeds threshold it only increases one dB for every 3 dB of input

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So our 91 dB peak (81dB over threshold) gets reduced to 37 dB (27 over threshold)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Apply a second 3:1 compressor to that 37dB peak (27 over threshold) and you will end up a 19 dB peak (9dB over threshold)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So yes stacking 2 x 3:1 compressors gives you the effective attenuation/ratio of a 9:1 compressor not a 6:1

author: Adam Thein
content: Best part of the thread is learning there’s somebody named Jerry Tubb out there

author: Berlin
content: and we all knew that in our heart of hearts

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Final score

Input signal 91dB
Compressor threshold 10dB

2 X 3:1 compressors - outputs 19dB
1 x 6:1 compressor - outputs 23.5dB
1 x 9:1 compressor - outputs 19dB

author: Will Pragnell
content: interesting quirk of all this though (just going back to Anthony's original example) - using ratios below 2:1, the multiplication result is smaller than the addition. so two 1.5:1 ratios in series would be equivalent to 2.25:1 rather than 3:1, for example

author: cian riordan
content: Mostly getting things to -9 (or intended level) somewhat quickly in the process and then working at that level for the duration of the mix. The louder and more dense the midrange at this level will start to peel away the ability for the low end to get through without dragging the whole mix down with it.

content: That canvas gets smaller and smaller the louder the overall mix gets, I've found in my travels.

author: Ted Whitten Media
content: Sorry for changing the subject briefly, gonna ressurect an old comment of mine because I figured it out... Wavelab has a batch replace function so if you're working off of a single long file that's been split into individual clips in the montage and want to replace with a new render, you don't have to replace each individually, you just  click "clips", then function, then batch replace and select the folder where the new render lives. It automatically matches things up by file name too.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The things I say here

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
And for lack of a better word philosophically, are how I approached this project

There was no “oh this is different/bigger so I’m gonna change how I do things”, the opposite is true. I doubled down and had to

So if you’ve read what I say here you can guess the signal chain, and what I did to mixes before I mastered. And more importantly if you’ve met with some of what I’ve written here you’ll have a good sense of *why* I did what I did 

But most of all I hope that you have a sense of the scale of Mastering’s contribution to a project like this. Let’s keep things in proportion and acknowledge the relative scale of invention and artistry in the songs, performances and production and what I did at the end

Not feigning humility, or diminishing my work. Just re stating why this work is compelling, and it’s not equilibrium

author: Montano Mastering
content: Question for the hive mind here. I have 310s with stereo subs (SVS SB3000) in a full GW build, with LCDX and HD650s for headphones. I find my HD650s present distortion in a much more forward and obvious way than both the mains and Audeze. Any reason why this would be the case, any solution so that I’m hearing it better elsewhere? Im almost always doing a QC with a combo of mains and LCDX but find that it’s good to do a once over with the sennheisers to make sure nothing is being pushed too hard. Is this par for the course to what anyone else’s process is/any similar experiences here?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: What’s the headphone amp?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I have 650 and would not consider them to be particularly revealing

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I guess the question is, are you sure this distortion you hear is not being added by your headphone chain

author: NoahNeedleman
content: There should be an emoji for Sensei.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Joe is consistently the best I’ve used

author: Montano Mastering
content: I don’t think it’s being added by the chain but I guess it’s possible. Or maybe it’s just distortion that’s there that is being compounded by the chain and thus more exaggerated.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So big picture, some thoughts

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: - What is our goal re distortion in mastering? Most modern music has tons of it on the way in and on the way out

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: - So with that a more pointed question is “what are problematic levels of distortion?”

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Yes, you’ll hear more on good headphones, but are you hearing enough on your mains

author: Montano Mastering
content: This is what Im running into difficulties with. What is a problematic level of distortion and not hearing enough on mains.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Separate the questions out

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: - what is a problematic amount of distortion?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: What kind of genres?

author: Montano Mastering
content: More often folk or folk pop. So genres with less harmonic content to disguise distortion perhaps?

author: Montano Mastering
content: It’s happened with two separate mixers. Slightly different problems - one where the team wants a louder sound so I’m struggling to get it loud without distortion. The other just an occasional occurrence, but has happened before with same mixer

author: Montano Mastering
content: Now that it’s happened across a couple projects I’m trying out find solutions to nip it in the bud/see it in advance of sending refs.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: This all Makes sense

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: For me I deliberately Don’t QC on headphones because it review Ala more than is practical in modern music

author: Montano Mastering
content: Ok that also checks out with my experiences in these projects/teams.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: To me the 310 are plenty revealing of issues, so these edge cases you have experienced are just that

author: Montano Mastering
content: Ok that is very good to hear.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Neither the 650 or LCD-X work for me

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Not bad, just not what I want

author: Tyson 'Jam' Ramela
content: Interesting. Did it behave differently depending on which genre you were working on or was it still heavy-handed nonetheless?

author: Austin Gordon
content: In general, really. Anything really transient-heavy I felt like it was more aggressive with. I would wager its best application would be for rounded, more organic and less compressed audio. It got the closest on a folk or soul-style song to working in a "natural" way when it was needed

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Set it to the transient/sustain  mode instead of left/right

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: And focus on snare in transient side

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I wouldn't fuss too much with attack and release

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: I generally don't turn projects down unless there were "real" problems of toxic behavior, not paying, etc. In this case there were a number of red flags before taking on the project that led me to believe it wouldn't be a great fit as far as what their expectations from mastering might be and that was exactly the case so I'm not surprised and I'm not sure if it's best to walk away from future work (which might seem odd since it was all positive interactions and they were happy with the end result), say something to hopefully improve future projects, or say nothing and accept that this will be how future projects will be

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Tricky in mastering — major label A&R don’t want my input, do the job.

Others — perhaps it’s time to say something and have a real impact

author: masteredbyjack
content: Fine line, but I’ve seen artists absolutely soar after focusing on the music and off the processing, of course it wasn’t due to me (or mastering), but in several cases it really did stem from discussions we had. So it’s very case by case (and what I’m referencing here is rare)

author: masteredbyjack
content:
One artist in particular -- everything we did would go to V4 (mostly because he was making small mix tweaks, etc). Great music. After awhile I suggested he work with a mix engineer, focus on the writing, playing, very intently. 

He did. Fast forward, many millions of streams, he quit his job, full time music, labels circling. Obviously it was all there already. In him. But do I think that me saying something sorta helped him get there faster? Yes.

Conventional wisdom would say mastering shouldn't say these things, but I'm not so sure

author: Will Pragnell
content: I don't know much, but I do know that "conventional wisdom" ain't all it's cracked up to be!

author: cian riordan
content: I’m also not using stereo wideners on kick drums and sub bass.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Zooming out I would say who cares what some big recent releases are doing? What matters to you?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Bar avoiding piling on more problems there’s very little we can do in mastering to improve mono compatibility, that ship has sailed in recording and mixing

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: In your specific example re the strings what is it that we could do? I’ve tried all of the “fixes” over the year and none work. I’m not sure how bad it would have to be for me to bring it up with the artist/producer/mixer but not something I have done in recent memory

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I do listen in mono a lot, I think it’s a really useful perspective but not because I am optimizing for mono compatibility

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: Translation to mono is cool, but it often happens by default, i.e. kick/snare/bass/lead vox are centered in the mix. Optimizing for mono is IMO counterproductive. M/S monoing the lows is a bummer. Pre-emptively worrying about hard-panned elements is a bummer.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: When Billie's "Bury a Friend" hits and the secondary bass + kick sounds are disturbingly stereoized, it's awesome. etc etc.

author: Rollmottle
content: This mix totally sounds normal to me and wouldn't have ever occurred to me to raise anything with the artist. Would do my thing and be on my way. So I guess my answer is no, I don't care about mono compatibility in 2025. If mono were critical to the intent of the song, it would have been baked by the team that way.

author: Will Pragnell
content: I think decreasing the overall width can do a little to improve the summed version and at least make those elemts present there, no? Of course it comes at a cost and you wouldn't want to do it in a way that compromises the stereo mix in a way that reduces the impact of the finished piece, but I think there's wiggle room here in some cases. I could be wrong

author: cian riordan
content: You can decrease width after stereo widening?

author: Will Pragnell
content: I'm not sure I understand the "after stereo widening" part of your question

author: Will Pragnell
content: But you can decrease the width of a stereo file whenever you like... what am I missing?

author: cian riordan
content: Issues with mono fold down typically come from stereo widening, not necessarily hard panning elements.

author: cian riordan
content: As in, MS widening, using phase to push the sides out.

author: Will Pragnell
content: Well they come from phase discrepancies between the signals on each side, right?

author: cian riordan
content: But pan two guitar takes left and right, they’ll sum just fine to mono.

author: Will Pragnell
content: Huh I'll have to play around. Maybe I've done a thinko here

author: cian riordan

There are folks out there doing good work top to bottom, but one thing I know to be true is when things are all done in the same BIG house, it's a gamble (looks at GZ). - big houses are like going to Starbucks, it's gonna be fine, in general for most people, but for the folks who care, it's just not good enough.

content: Also - some factory's range of acceptable quality is quite narrow, and others are quite large. Every factory has a different QC tolerance policy.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: It's worth considering what Mastering is for, and the key thing here is an objective new set of ears. So as the guys have said above I suggest hanging back and just watchig and listening. I'd go further and suggest that you say to the M.E. "Hey, thanks for having me here. Please do not change who you do things for me"

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Depending on the Engineers experience they may spend more or less energy making sure you are happy with things, I would try to avoid that if you can. If their room is decent it will probably sound awesome in there, which means exactly zero in the real world for you

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But again different styles, some cool records have been finished with very collaborative Mastering styles. It's not for me (on the first pass) but it does work for some

author: Berlin
content:
I think jamming references tracks is a great way to warm up your ears maybe, give yourself a sort of zero reset in the morning before work. 

But I wouldn't reference anything against a mix I receive to master. Even when given references by the artist - do the work first, then reference (if you want to). The mix should give you everything you need to know, want to do.. it's there in the track.

author: Berlin
content: Most folks really love their mixes, it's important to remember that.

author: Berlin
content: and then you send it back and the artist and producer are like.. "ummm... it changed alot".

author: Berlin
content: That being said, I do love Orphans by Coldplay. Haha.. helps me remember that I don't need to make things bright.

author: Berlin
content: Every so often one of us in here pops into the channel "Well.. i did it again, and I changed the mix too much, I gotta remember people love their mixes." haha

author: Berlin
content: I was just sitting here thinking about how when I was starting out mastering, and I know so much of this is just ego / hubris, but years ago I used to have the thought often, "I just saved that record" or "I am saving this record". And now so many of the mixes are just so dam good that I say so often to myself "Don't fuck this record up" and "do less" and "get out of the way, the mix is great". - But I'm also more confident than ever. Confident in my ability to recognize when to implement something and not..

author: Bryan DiMaio
content:
This'll get you there quick and dirty:
- Duplicate naughty word section of the full bounce
- Music Rebalance one copy to have no vocals
- Music Rebalance one copy to have only vocals
- Reverse/mess around with naughty word to mask artifacts
- Bounce with them together

I ride sections .1 .2db (rarely more .3 if I’m going fucking wild) up or down. Can make all the difference. Sometime the outro chorus has additional backing vocals or instrumentation, so I’ll bump that a different value than say the first chorus, but usually volume rides are the same value for intro’s breakdowns verses and chorus’s

author: Berlin
content:
There are a couple ways to go about it for me, either soloing tracks, or you can also select and export clips.. But the clips will be exported as they are named in/on the program, not as the track titles. - your clip length has to be correct as well as it will ignore the track markers this way. 

Most of the time, Just soloing my "inst" track and exporting with a .INST suffix preset works just fine and isn't much of a hassle.

I’m very late to this conversation…and it seems like you’ve all moved on to talk about more technical things.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: I get a spark of excitement all the time but it's more so from the perspective of experiencing something new rather than doing something creative. That's probably one of the main reasons I ended up in mastering. I've done pretty much everything else like performing, recording, mixing, producing, working as an orchestrator, working as a copyist... I have 2 composition degrees... I enjoyed doing all of those things but am happy to only do mastering now. I was never very interested in the creative aspect of writing music so my situation might be a little different though

author: Beck Nebel
content: I do think this is where my tension lies. I’d love to be able to work on truly great music. This doesn’t mean “big” music. I do think a full commitment is in my future. author: Rob Domos
content: Fully digital routing?

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: No. No internal clock

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: If fills a buffer in memory

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Data in buffer is the same

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: What happens after that is up to your audio interface

author: Rob Domos
content: Maybe buffer size makes a difference to my interface or something?

author: Rob Domos
content: Doesn’t logically make sense to me that it would

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Buffer size is just set by the interface and that wouldn’t change anything about the output

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Either the buffer is filled or it isn’t and you get a dropout

author: Rob Domos
content: So all apps everywhere slave their buffer size to be synchronous with the interface?

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: I guess there could be an argument for an interface behaving differently based on buffer size and something relating to noise on USB but idk enough about how interfaces work to know if that is possible and if it was, it should be a minuscule effect

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Apps just fill the buffer

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: When they’re done filling they sleep until the audio has played and buffer is ready to be filled again (obviously this is very simplified)

author: Rob Domos
content: Is there any chance of only a single sample being dropped and that audibly presenting more as a distortion than a dropout, especially post reconstruction filter?

author: Rob Domos
content: (Btw I know I’m saying nonsense I just don’t know when because I’m out of my depth)

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: If a sample was wrong then the files wouldn’t null

author: Rob Domos
content: I was talking about in handoff to the interface, but you’re saying full buffers are handed to the interface

author: Rob Domos
content: I fully understand that the classical explanations don’t allow for what I’m describing. I’m just wondering if the classical explanations may be oversimplified or something

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: I don’t know the exact implemention so it could be something like a circular buffer that’s constantly filled but it’s effectively all the same

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: There are some exceptions that relate to noise but it’s generally not going to be a problem or audible (and something you can’t measure with an audio precision…). There was at least one streamer on the market where playing flac files sounded different than wav because the extra processing to decode created noise in the unit. In the case of an interface connected via usb that would be less likely and depend on how susceptible the interface is to being affected by noise on the usb connection

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: So theoretically your computer running with a higher load in one program could generate more noise on usb but again we’re splitting hairs and it most likely won’t be an issue

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Looking at one gui vs another will bias you much more than that ever would

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: And that could be easily tested by running benchmarking software while listening

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: But this gets you down the audiophile rabbit hole of putting linear power supplies on your computer and special USB cards which cost thousands of dollars all of which is mostly nonsense

author: Austin Gordon
content:
Quick question for the group: when it comes to vetting mixes to determine whether or not they're "ready" for mastering, how do you guys approach discerning what is artist or producer/mixer intention vs. an "issue" that needs to be addressed and possibly sent back to the mixer to take a look at? Any best practices?

I want to make sure that I'm honoring the mix, of course, but also not leave any necessary stones unturned, so to speak.

author: Rollmottle
content: I always assume everything in a mix is intentional unless there's an obvious, breaking technical error like an audible gap or something similar

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: I would want to be informed if something was obviously technically wrong in my mix. Like if the kick drum was muted, or the lead vocal was panned hard left, or there were obvious bad edits making loud pops.

author: Rollmottle
content: If in doubt, I will reach out and ask for a quick check with a timestamp, but that is very infrequent.

author: Elaine Rasnake
content: I'll usually reply back to the artist and note the things that I heard that personally felt off and ask if it was intentional, ie: "I noticed the vocals are completely buried in the second verse unlike the rest of the song. Was this intentional?"

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: I'm also pretty open to hearing from the ME if they want to reach out about whatever. But I prefer not to be put on blast to the full email chain, e.g. "Hi everybody, there's a pop on the downbeat of chorus 2, maybe Jonathan could take a look at that spot and send a new pass," when in fact it's a purposeful foot stomp mixed purposely loud.

author: Elaine Rasnake
content: It's always best to double check especially if you work with any DIY-type artists who are doing everything themselves

author: Austin Gordon
content: This is helpful to know, and also a necessary reminder to practice discretion whenever possible, I'm not interested in putting anyone on blast. 😅

author: Railtown Mastering
content: Agree with above. Pretty rare for me to flag something unless a blatant tech issue that there’s no way for me address. People don’t generally send their mixes to mastering if they don’t like them. If I’m genuinely concerned about something that’s walking the line of creative, I might pick up the phone and ask some open ended questions about intent, but I’m not going to call you and say I don’t like or agree with what you did. Not vetting mixes or telling people whether or not they’re ready.

author: Rollmottle
content: I would exercise caution in reaching out about things that can be attributed to taste or artistic choice. One person's "vocals being buried" is another person's "contrast."

author: Austin Gordon
content: I wouldn't want to antangonize anyone or even accidentally imply that the bass guitar was mixed poorly, in this instance.

author: Austin Gordon
content: But like @Rollmottle said, I have historically always deferred to the fact that if the mix was approved, then it must be intentional.

author: Rollmottle
content: Does it change your approach if you assume they like it that way?

author: Austin Gordon
content: Great question! I would say yes, because what one person might consider to be distracting, another might consider to be "vibey".

author: Austin Gordon
content: Exactly, I wouldn't want someone to come back and think that I wasn't doing my job or overlooked something in error.

author: Rollmottle
content: it's not my place to attribute "correctness" to artistic choices. outside of the obvious technical error,  assume there are no mistakes and honor what's there. as my colleague says, love it for what it is, not for what it isn't.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: What's your response when the artist specifically wants changes? Low end to be punchy like this record and make the highs silky while smoothing out the vocals...

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: It's not generally the type of project I aim to work on but when it comes up I'll usually just go with it rather than pushing back and suggesting they may want to get the mix to a point they're happier with rather than expecting me to essentially finish the mix

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Honestly? I pretty much ignore direction and go where the music wants to go. The reason it works is because the artist has spent months, or maybe even a lifetime imbuing the songs and performances and recordings with intent, most of it at a subconscious level. And when I honor *that* work they generally just go “yeah, this is great”

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I’m not overt in that, and it’s not a way of working that every ME should consider. But as someone who is highly sensitive, I get better results turning that sensitivity towards the music rather than the  words from team

author: SawyerM
content: This is some really helpful insight. I was wondering if you could expand on where you most often look find intent. Is it in the minutiae or bigger picture?

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content:
I don't agree with this last part. Just because they want it a certain way doesn't mean the project has ended up that way. They got a beat from a producer friend who's been doing this for a month, recorded vocals in their bedroom with the one USB mic they have, mixed it constantly referencing their favorite warm record, aren't happy with how closely they got it and now want you to make it closer to their favorite record. 
My intuitive approach of leaning into what they have would likely not meet their expectations for strong-arming the mix into something it's not

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: That's generally an exaggeration but I have been in plenty of situations like that

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: I used to push back a little more and suggest they maybe try to get the mix a little closer to what they're after but I think in most cases it's not beneficial and will just give them more doubt about the project so I'd rather roll with it and do the best I can to meet their expectations even if I don't necessarily agree in the sense that I don't think the project benefits from pushing it in a certain direction

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: It’s all in the music

content: I’m actually looking to avoid a stamp!

content: Want it to sound like I was never there

author: Edsel Holden
content:
I live this and have lived this for sure and now days I think of it like... "if they love it, everyone did their job right and I was *wrong*"

If they don't love it - "now they have learned that mastering is not what they are *missing* and they can create more music with more confidence going forward" 

either way - you serve them and they level up 

in one way by completing a creative cycle

in another way by THEM learning more about their current creative cycle and taking that and aplying to to the next cycle

author: masteredbyjack
content: Not sure if in response to above, but I’d go with human operating AI. Easier to bounce back and become more skilled at that

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Also, in a mastering sense, if we broadly define mastering as finishing a record (which I do), I’d argue AI has the potential (and does) to increase the amount of uncertainty in the record making process

So being someone with the skills du jour, whatever those are, to apply your taste and get records done could be even more valuable

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The different frequency/distortion etc between mix and master make a matching number meaningless

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I spend about 5 seconds matching level by ear of if I wanna do a comparison and then just listen

author: Victor Garcia
content:
For me it’s always a matter of vibe and knowing which tool will fit the job. And doing it “fast”
Once I have it done and I’m happy I bounce down the track (or tracks) and do that level matching thing. After that I watch an episode of The Office 😇

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
I would say as a general statement that I’m not sure it’s helpful to be too tied to a ref mix, or beating it. These days I’m really focussed on what the songs and mixes want to be, and while I’ll compare to REFs I would say it might be 5 or 10 mins of listening out of a whole day of mastering

There are some projects when mixed by someone like Serban or Alex Ghenea that there is more comparison (very little room for change there), and many where there is basically none (“oh! Refs suck, won’t be listening again”)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Louder is better is a trap we all fall into earlier on, and level matching with some honesty is a good antidote, but needs to be wielded with a light touch

author: Victor Garcia
content: I don’t think matching and comparing is flawed if it doesn’t takes time of being creative and any attention. I really love to have a quick listen at the same level once all art and all decisions have been made. In fact it’s the right moment for me before taking a brake

Avoid at all costs!

author: mcsnare
content: Everyone’s journey is different. I’ve always considered my 20+ years as a recording engineer, mixer, and producer to be an advantage.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So, I’m reading this as “sometimes we should do a lot and sometimes we should do less, in both mixing and mastering”

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: And that makes total sense

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But the question I think was more how has recording/mixing/producing informed your mastering work?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I can see obvious advantages, but I’d love to hear what they were/are for you

author: mcsnare
content: One of the things I learned and tried to achieve during my mixing days was a strong desire to go to any lengths to get a great vocal sound.

author: mcsnare
content: I still have this inner voice while I’m mastering that says “the vocal is still not where it could be”

author: mcsnare
content: My first and last thought is usually how is the vocal sounding?

author: mcsnare
content: It’s what I always start with when turning knobs or moving the mouse.

author: mcsnare
content: This is why I always have at least one or more eq’s in M/S

author: mcsnare
content: I have 3 analog de-essers and at least 3 plug ins I try if needed which for me is about 75% of the time.

author: mcsnare
content: It’s only after I get the vocal sounding great to me, I’ll adjust anything else. Frequently it’s a process of circling back after addressing other things.

author: mcsnare
content: I also do a ton of instrumental music and what I said applies to the primary melodic instrument in those cases.

author: mcsnare
content: Having done a lot of mixing, as I said, I’m very comfortable doing what traditional ME’s might consider to be too much processing.

author: mcsnare
content: Having said all this, there are PLENTY of days where I have .5db at 1700 or 2500 in the M channel and Bob’s your uncle.

author: mcsnare
content: I do a lot of A/Bing so that I am aware of where I’m sitting with the treatment causing a loss of purity that the untouched mix has.

author: mcsnare
content: As long as my result exceeds the unavoidable loss of purity, I’m good.

author: mcsnare
content: To the girls and guys that have been mastering for maybe 4 or 5 years: when you get a mix that is both shitty sounding AND too loud (or the you have to match the loud ref), if throw up your hands and say not anything (or much) I can do with this, think again. In that situation I’ll give it lipo, face reconstruction, AND make it louder than the loud ref.

author: mcsnare
content: When I was at Sterling all the senior dudes operated like this.

author: masteredbyjack
content: Also the @Nomograph Mastering "you don't have to like it but you gotta love it" is a guiding principle, one of the great unlocks for me

author: mcsnare
content: One of my big unlocks was a convo I had with Ted J one time.

author: masteredbyjack
content: Expand please if you are willing!

author: mcsnare
content: I told him I was working on a Helmet record but it was really harsh and I couldn’t listen at my normal level.

author: mcsnare
content: He said well,  do whatever you need to to be able to crank it without it bumming you out.

author: Nick Stetina
content: Basically permission to do whatever it takes?

author: mcsnare
content: Ted was the first ME I saw that used loads of plugs to manipulate.

author: mcsnare
content: He was doing that 25 years ago.

author: mcsnare
content: A big no no in those days.

author: mcsnare
content: I didn’t mention that I had already started to shift into mastering. 😀 that session was gold for me.

author: mcsnare
content: During my mix career I always attended just so I could learn from the greats. NOT so I could get mix technique suggestions.

author: mcsnare
content: Ted, Bernie, Big Bass Brian, Ludwig, Calbi, Marcussen, Doug Sax

author: mcsnare
content: I quietly watched. Politely and strategically asked questions, and soaked everything up.

author: mcsnare
content: Scot Hull was a key early mentor. In the earliest days Brad Blackwell, as well.

author: mcsnare
content: Mixing and mastering at the top level is like driving a sports car at top speed towards a wall and knowing exactly when to hit the brakes to stop inches from the wall.

author: mcsnare
content: The closer to the wall you stop is a commonality for all the legends. TLA once told me “I don’t do anything different from any other mixer, I just go farther.”

author: mcsnare
content: Having had the benefit of learning so much from others on my journey, at this point - especially since I’m inching toward retirement - it’s important to me to try and give back to others. And this seems to be a great community to do that kind of stuff.

author: Victor Garcia
content: @mcsnare 🙌🏼 Thank you

author: mcsnare
content: @Nomograph Mastering is 100% correct about eq.

author: mcsnare
content: All I can say about that is the old school dudes at Sterling JUMPED in to M/S once Muth made those consoles.

author: mcsnare
content: Marino - all day, everyday. He told me once he seldom added side level but consistently eq’d in M/S

author: mcsnare
content: Their attitude was summed up by chief tech Barry Wolfson -“it’s like a three legged stool, it’s never wrong!”

author: mcsnare
content: I do think however, if you listen very closely, there was/is a purity to the West Coast sound that is different than that NY school.

author: mcsnare
content: I don’t know if those differences exist as much today.

author: mcsnare
content: And that purity versus the by any means necessary school is very much a mixing thing as well.

author: masteredbyjack

author: chrissorem
content: This has happened on a few occasions and has always worked out well but the people (usually a band mixing their own record or a producer) that sent mixes this way to me basically did the best they could and were very open and wanting to significant change. I can’t think of a reason why a pro mixer would ever do this.

author: masteredbyjack
content: Very agree with Edsel

author: masteredbyjack
content: But also to @chrissorem point, usually the record is best when everyone takes it as far as they can, "leaving space for mastering to do it's thing" often is not as good as mixer going all the way and then us picking up the ball, which still we may do a lot or take it further if it's called for

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Maybe I'm also out of the majority here @Edsel Holden but my thinking is...if you are mixing, you have the ENTIRE picture right in front of you, your can react to anything. Push and pull, moves, etc. All up. You don't live in the world of tradeoffs we do really. At least not as much 

So almost any move is better made there. What we are is a new lens and view, so we can hopefully see the record different and add something you would not as a mixer, by virture of us being different humans who listen differently.

author: masteredbyjack

author: masteredbyjack

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: Edsel Holden
content:
quick reasons that come to mind

BC collaboration can unlock doors you cannot see alone

& That "global" kind of move is something that a mixer may not have visibility to, but can be obvious from the finishing perspective 

I am not saying this is ideal or best, just saying its not EVIL and im totally open to it and I know lots of great records I love were not "finished" by each (important) team member ... 

I would never ASK for this but I would also never tell a team or mixer "hey dudde.... finish it first" - I would just finish it. I know you all would too !

author: Halliemmelton

author: Halliemmelton

author: Austin Gordon
content: I agree with all of this, I've been bitten in the ass twice now in the last few months, but both times it was a single for an indie artist who decided after the fact to just not finish the song or go in a completely different direction, rather than take the files and then not pay me. Not a huge loss finanicially, but still, in principle having worked and not be compensated for my time is something I'm trying to avoid happening again

author: chrissorem
content: I’ve been making records for 20 years and have always invoiced after I’m done with the work.  I’ve never been on the short end of that stick as most of my work is from a place of shared community and mutual respect. People who know you are on their team aren’t usually trying to screw you.  That being said, I had a situation recently where  I Finished a mix and 3 months went by without getting paid. The red flag here was poor communication from their end.  Not responding to emails or texts for weeks ect. In which I gave them the benefit of the doubt. After no response and not being paid I started to write this off as a loss, but I  then continued to contact them every other day. ( hey I hope everything is ok, did you receive my email ? I’d love to settle up) ect.  Finally I was paid in full and I won’t work with them again and I’ve changed nothing on my end.  If it were two months of work I’d might ask for a deposit but like @Rollmottle  mentioned I prefer to trust in people

author: Austin Gordon
content: Absolutely, I hate that you had to hound them like that but I'm glad it worked out for better or worse

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Unless you've been given delivery specs, I'd find a few references and go off of that. Just be careful to find something intended for the same format you're going for (theatrical, online streaming, etc). Netflix and DVDs/Blu-ray can be a good reference but at the same time things generally get remixed for that so the levels may be different from the original theatrical levels

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: I’m pretty sure you’ll run into problems trying to run a DAW in Parallels. You need a lower level virtualization that runs directly on the hardware instead of through the Mac OS. Even if you do get the drivers working, you’ll likely have problems with dropouts

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: It’s the same reason you can’t run games very well either even though the Apple Silicon can have decent GPU performance

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Theoretically you should be able to run any program but anything that requires any kind of realtime performance (audio, gaming, other graphics simulation) isn’t going to work very well

author: Rob Domos
content: The best career advice I ever got was from a close friend of mine who I watched rise up from an immigrant with few resources to becoming a director at Instacart leading a huge wing of software engineers and a millionaire by the time he hit 30. He said that a mentor of his told him that nobody will ever promote you until you already have a track record of doing the role you’d be promoted into, so at a fundamental level, you have to do a ton of uncompensated work to advance

author: Rollmottle
content: Alarming to me how so few of my younger colleagues understand this. And you need to be doing it at the next level for at least 6 months to a year to even have a real conversation about actually getting promoted

author: Berlin

author: Rollmottle
content:
Couple thoughts here...I have a lot of experience making, producing and mastering this kind of music. 

TL;DR Don’t be afraid to be heavy handed.

As with everything, everything depends on everything. Generally speaking, I find the moves can be way bigger than they’d be in a typical song with a vocal (eg .35db vs 6db+). Don’t be afraid of huge boosts to pull out what’s there. Invariably, there’s interesting textures there in the synths in the upper registers that can help make the track come to life.  Saturation can be your friend. This kind of music and take a lot of processing before falling apart or changing the intent. Don’t be afraid to lean into what’s there. 

The kick and bass is ultimately what's going to make or break the track, so make sure you're using your calories to get that right before adding anything up top. Get the low end hitting and maybe you'll find the mids and highs are fine as is.

I didn’t think about the fact that noise being uncorrelated means it doesn’t fit neatly into either of these detected categories. When some of the noise goes to one stem and some goes to another arbitrarily it can create some slight pumping in the noise that isn’t desirable.

I know some tools detect noise and make it its own stem, but it’s rare for me to find the level of flexibility I’d like

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I think @Nomograph Mastering as always has great words to frame things like this.

As a quick anecdote that recently happened -- I worked on a project where one mix was done by super A-list guy, and another done by non-A list (still very good mix). The management I was talking to relayed to me -- the artists were saying they needed more "active mastering" on the non-A-list mix, and the manager told them "no, you just need someone who is good and who actually listens". I thought that was a great way to put it. Just listen to the record and what it is asking for (usually not all the color and stuff stuff stuff). And on the off chance it needs extra extra, just go there since the art wants it, removing the ego yada yada.

Turns out, the moves dones are what I would consider "the same amount" to both mixes (minus some volume stuff, which one needed to be pumped up a bit to make sense)

author: masteredbyjack
content: Often find what @Nomograph Mastering cited in that oft-quoted interview with him and Dale -- the story of what someone says about the song, "it needs this or that etc" often doesn't actually match what comes out of the speakers, and what actually does come out is really quite compelling if you are available to it, and carries what the people are wanting already

Lots of reasons for a quiet record too, and it might not be the mastering, but rather the length of the side and how dense the program material is. 

That is a big big determiner of the level of a cut. 

If you pull 5 different LPs out of your collection and AB them, they will all be different levels because they are all different lengths.

author: Montano Mastering
content:
Hey friends. Question about DMM vs. Lacquer. Ive had both done on my masters and am aware of what each process is and offers. I’ve also some searching here and haven’t seen this specifically brought up so hopefully not being redundant. 

I am working with a high profile Dance Electronic Artist/Singer - curious if there are any merits to DMM over lacquer specifically for this genre, where we’re not necessarily after warmth but a sharper high end and transient detail may play better. 

Does anyone have any thoughts or experience in something so specific?

author: aliberger
content: i can't speak to what DMM is like now, but some of my favorite dance records (i'm obsessed with like 1985-1992 stuff) were done with DMM and sound great, especially in clubs. thinking about the label Strictly Rhythm specifically. fwiw though a lot of what they were putting out was probably coming in with a different frequency balance than contemporary stuff, being made on SP1200s etc

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Whatever bit depth you start with (16/24/32) once you start processing in a DAW it becomes a 32 or 64 bit floating point number which must be converted back to a 24 bit integer (or less) file to playback through your DAC

author: hyanrarvey
content: You can get some dope ass rounding errors tho lol

author: Dalliance
content: I see! So as Ableton for instance defaults to 32 bit whenever anything gets printed in the session. I always thought that was a pseudo conversion of the file (common sense: how can something that has always been 24bit become 32bit). That means common sense isn’t sensing in this case 😂

author: hyanrarvey
content: And the math to go between them is actually insane

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The internal processing depth is always 32 or 64 float (these days) . That is entirely independent of export settings

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: When we make short words longer - say 24 to 32 the LSBs (least significant bits are “padded” with zeros

content: But if you really want to understand you’ll need to go a little deeper

author: Berlin
content:
I second @masteredbyjack @Nick Stetina. There is a .v1 .v2 .v3 suffix and so on to every montage change/update and a folder to accompany.

I also append my exports to correlate to the montage number and not the version of the song. i.e. if track 2 has a change on montage .v4, it is now .v4. Even if it’s only the second time that particular song has changed. I also update my samply player this way. All numbers correlate.

this is what works for me!

author: Austin Gordon
content: Yep, I second @Berlin and @masteredbyjack as well. I have all of my montages in WaveLab named with "V1", "V2" suffixes, etc. I also separate each render into its own montage, so "2496", "2448", and so on. This does add a little bit of clutter but it's worth it to have a separate montage to always reference back to if there's an issue with a file, which has happened in rare instances.

author: Val ᶠʳ
content:
The funny story behind the creation of Reaper, is that Justin Frankel, was in early 2000's messing with Pro Tools. He found a bug, and a fix. He reported it to the PT dev team, and then received an email telling him something like his guarantee was now void, because he modified the code of the software. 
Then he decided to create his own DAW 🙂

I used a scheduler for a while, but now set up on using notion for calendar and project management.

as far as folks not getting your files when they say, that’s the name of the game and u just gotta ride the wave, scheduler or not. be easy to work with. pencil in their project and touch base on the days / weeks leading up. move their project down the line if needed. keep communication open and easy and don’t rush them. 

big part of our job is making it happen with a great attitude. 

some weeks i’m drowning and other weeks i wish more was happening. take it in stride.

author: Berlin
content: but very simply, gcal has everything u need at this point, even appointment scheduling.

author: East End
content: ok noted, i'll look into it. Thanks!

author: Berlin
content: notion is highly customizable if u have time to set up the ecosystem. i am enjoying it.

author: DarrenB
content: I find Notion really handy for not just scheduling but also contacts/CRM and how it all integrates together.  Took a second to figure it out but once you're going it's solid.

author: DarrenB
content: We can take this to DM's if it's not helpful for others but I have it setup so contacts/CRM talk to calendar and vice versa.  At a glance I can see where a project is at (pending, waiting for files, out for review, approved, paid, etc.), links to where things live, links to their email, Samply, Dropbox, Socials, basically whatever info I need at any time.  I don't have mine automated to trigger the various states but that's possible too.  It was a bit confusing at first but once you learn their methodology and get setup it's fairly straightforward.  I did find it helpful to think through how I wanted things to run before I set it up, that probably saved some headaches.

author: masteredbyjack

The question that seems to get asked a lot is “what if it can do more for me?” Which is a great one.

The question I use it to answer is “how can I see ONLY the essential things I need, no more and no less” so I can fly

author: masteredbyjack
content: The automations I mean. The manual-ness to me is a form of QC on the interactions we do

author: masteredbyjack
content: Just sent you a DM, I have a short vid of how I use it

author: masteredbyjack
content:
My 2 cents, take it or leave it -- if there is any correlation -- the earlier someone reaches out to me, the less likely they are to hit whatever deadline they say the mixes are coming.

Being flexible is a massive part of the game -- anything we can do to make things go smoothly is very worth it IMO, artists and teams have so many balls in the air getting a project across the line, the last thing they need is mastering demanding (or even nudging) to get files because it fits our life.

Also, did away with any booking on my site this year (I'd say only like 1 of 100 projects would even do that anyway), much better. Smoother. Faster for all in the rare instance it happened.

author: Berlin
content: the man with the vids

author: Berlin
content:
we basically use notion from the calendar view - we create a new event, and it loads a default card that we made with all of the fields we need for billing, QB invoice links & payment status, metadata, files, players, links, track lists, deliverable types, project status, etc etc. 

we fill in the blanks from email threads, manually. 

then we just move them on down the line as needed. can massage the schedule as needed. 

once a project is complete, it’s marked complete and moved to an archive.

author: David Fuller
content:
@cartierdad FWIW I went through a *lot* of speakers when I demoed stuff a couple years back; the 420s, the ATC 50s, and the DD8Cs were very easily top three for me. The 420s had the distinct advantage of being *way* less expensive than the other two. 

However I will note a couple of things about them that may make you go a different direction. 

1,  they are *big* speakers and will need beefy stands that can drop their platform low. 
2, they really don't integrate at less than ~5ft so if your plan is to use them more nearfield, don't.

content:
I've been working so hard to reroute my thinking re: cleaning things up that "stick out too much". 
The idea or narrative is that mastering is helping clean things up and tucking everything in and forgetting that emphasizing certain elements, even when it's "sticking out", is just as important.
For me personally though, it's easier said than done and a daily practice of not sanding down the sculpture into a bland orb

author: Slow Hand
content: Was speaking with a mixer of note about this the other day. How can anyone outside of the artist's circle make a judgement about the quality of their mixes (or masters) without hearing the before and after? Well, you can't. At least you can't hear the difference between each stage. We only get to hear the end result.

author: Slow Hand
content:
It sure would be cool (and informative) to give people access to the before and after, though.  I'd like to see someone make a website that documents the journey and process of a song:

**1. **First demo/phone recording.
**2.** Fleshing out and refining the song.
**3.** Landing on an amazing bridge that *really* clicks, scrapping 90% of the song, and then starting over with that killer bridge as the chorus.
**4.** Final song.
**5.** Arranging
**6.** Tracking.
**7. **Overdubbing.
**8.** Editing and tuning.
**9.** Mixing.
**10.** Mastering.
**11.** Obliterated by FM radio.

Host it all as a web page that details each step and gives comparative examples.

author: Mike Tierney
content:
I have this script titled "Set Project Title.lua"

bool, projname = reaper.GetSetProjectInfo_String(0, "PROJECT_NAME", "", true)
projname = string.sub(projname, 10, -5)
reaper.GetSetProjectInfo_String(0, "PROJECT_TITLE", projname, true)

I'm pretty sure the way that this script works is that it sets the string to "20250902 Example.RPP" (quotation marks included). Then it skips the first ten characters and the last five. Then sets the project name based on what's left, which in this case is just Example. Then for Wildcards I just use $title

The upgrade costs $595. The most recent version available is Sequoia 17, and you can find the list of new features here:
https://borisfx.com/products/sequoia/#whats-new

Please note that you’ll need to upgrade to a Boris FX license in order to receive support from Boris FX.

For your current "Magix" version, any support inquiries would still need to be handled through the Magix support forums.

author: Rob Domos
content:
One thing to note here is that a perpetual attitude of “Yep! Coming right up!” contributes to one’s success at least as much as sounding good does, if not more (I suspect more).

Of course there is a line where the best move is to course correct, but IMO it’s wayyy past this point. If someone is on their 11th unusual complicated ask that didn’t move the ball forward even slightly, I’ll be thinking of ways to reign things in that will come across as me guiding the process towards what would be most helpful to them. At no point would I frame things as “xyz isn’t worth my time”

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: What is the end goal?

author: masteredbyjack
content:
My advice is to keep going above and beyond. Sure, sometimes people are ridiculous (even if they don’t know it or mean to be). But I can’t tell you how many doors it’s opened for me, people who I never would have guessed remembered the above and beyond and went to bat for me. 

It all sorts itself out. And you’ll have other people who are a breeze and even it out. It’s the long game that matters

author: masteredbyjack
content: Also — all, and I mean ALL of the top MEs I look up to ( @Nomograph Mastering especially) go way above and beyond in ways it’s probably even hard to comprehend. A surprise they are at the top of the game? I think not

author: miguel @ knurlmastering
content: Although Reaper has a steep learning curve, it’s easily the best DAW for mastering. Everything you need is available within a single application, eliminating the hassle of switching between multiple programs. It can handle virtually anything you throw at it, and once you start customizing it with scripts, it becomes the most efficient DAWs for mastering. The only real challenge is getting past that initial learning curve.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Reaper people love it, but I’d argue the endless customization for a beginner to mastering could be a real downside and take your eye off the ball of what matters

Also would push back on any statements like “easily the best DAW for x”. Dependent on person

author: masteredbyjack
content: I'm not here for any sweeping generalities like this. The world is shades of gray. Sorry.

author: masteredbyjack
content: I want to help a new comer find something that works for him

author: masteredbyjack
content: Not argue about what DAW is better

author: Elaine Rasnake
content: But again that's because I'm the type of engineer that would rather spend a couple months tweaking settings until my personal "perfection" and not everyone's like that

author: Ted Whitten Media
content: Feature sets and capabilities don't automatically make it the best for everyone. It's a highly individual thing, and not everyone is going to thrive with that kind of DAW.

author: miguel @ knurlmastering
content:
We’re all here to help and share. Just because I have a different opinion doesn’t mean I’m not trying to help.

Just because something may be the best at one task, that doesn’t mean you’re wrong for choosing something else simply because you prefer it. More than one thing can be true at the same time, Reaper may have the best feature set and capabilities for mastering, but that doesn’t mean you’re wrong for not using it or for preferring other tools. And, like I said before, the learning curve is a real problem so I get people not wanting to go through that!

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: You want to be be pushing into the above something like 6dB below 0dBFS, and then us ethe clip fader on the Standardclip to get a dB or two happening on your snares and maybe kicks

author: NoahNeedleman
content: What does “make sense” mean with regard to 80 160 320. 80 loudest, 160 & 320 quieter respectively?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Great question, that’s not all that clear here (made 8% more sense in it’s original context)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Make sense really means that they relate musically. Often with a lot of saturation 160 or 320 can be too much, or if someone is trying to juice energy they get carried away with 40 or 80 where some 160 might tell the story better

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: But a better piece of advice here *might* be make sure that the overall low end (40 to say 200) is under control, and if you want to highlight something find what moves the song along (might be 120 in funk, but 40 in hip hop)
