author: chrissorem
content: The solution is easy, If you don’t like it don’t do it.  The reality of record making is we have no idea(unless you were involved) why things end up the way they end up. It really doesn’t matter either. Everyone likes different things, to you it might sound harsh to the artist it could be energy.  Define your taste,  try your best to make things sound the way you hear it.  Any experienced mixer or ME has been in situations where they might not be psyched  on every decision but that sometimes comes with the gig. The best way around it is to politely back  out if you don’t stand by it or make your own music they way you want. This has helped me not be judgmental but define what I like

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Good points all. 

To your last point though;

“The enemy of art is indifference “ 

I would say in my practical experience in a record making town that I encounter almost no indifference, but what I do encounter all the time is engineers who are failing to meet the music because they’re focussed on the wrong things 

- these files are 16 bit!
- I can’t believed they used a Claret to record the vocals 
- I would never use splice!!

Etc etc 

Re taste I may have said this on the Dead Wax podcast … it’s entirely unreasonable to think that you will like everything you hear, but as a working pro it’s crucial to be able to understand why other people might (and not without cynical recourse to “they’re sheep!!”)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I think it probably seems like I offer “meet the music” as some kind of panacea, but having struggled with it for decades I really believe it is

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: There’s so much energy, connection, inspiration et available if you can just be fully available to the music. For me in my work life it’s where the heavy lift is - what do I need to do to really meet this next song

author: aliberger
content: i know this is mastering talk and not approaching all of life talk, but i find some variation of this perspective is really helpful for me in most situations especially interpersonally. coming in with rigid ideas/concepts/rules/unilateral expectations creates so much friction, whereas being open/relaxed/curious helps things go smoothly and maybe everyone discovers something new

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Agree with you! I don’t think anyone was questioning the OP’s right to critique, and as you say it’s a key part of developing taste

But the original question does betray the idea that there is some kind of objective correct answer or way to Mix and Master things, or that as listeners to end product we have insight into the constraints the teams were under when delivering their work

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
With great appreciation for the civility and depth of discourse on the topic, I’d like to push back on the “competency-based hierarchy” as it pertains to music. 

The *job* may be engineering, but in music, how we approach and interact with others has a direct effect on the subjective outcomes. 

IME, assuming that all egos are strong enough for the work to be discussed as if separate from the person is a recipe for a bad time. 

If we’re not engaging the people first, the work suffers.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: 100% agree. But also, bedside manner matters.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Totally, but where is it slotted in the order of importance? I’ve learned far more from the people that were brisk but got it right than I did from the people that coddled. 

Having said that, much like photographers, most of the really great producers I’ve worked with have been great hangs… it’s important to be able to connect with the artist, it leads to great work. But where theyre soft with the artist, they’re direct with their peers. The amount of times I’ve seen Max Martin go “no, that’s not good” to one of his producers or writers… ain’t no one got time for the handholding. They got jobs to do. And everyone does better because of it, which I think is better? Short term pain for long term gain?

author: BatMeckley
content: If i was captain of a ship, and there was a hole in the hull, i want the first mate to be like “yo, our hull fucked up. We’re taking in water”. If they’re like “so cap, you’re a really great cap, and I think you’re great at navigating the ocean, and I don’t want you to take this as a criticism on your navigational skills, but I think a little while ago we MAYBE steered in to a reef and I’m not saying it’s your fault, it could be ALL of our faults for all we know, but it seems there might be a tiny breech in the hull and a bit of moisture might, MAYBE, be accumulating, in a way that’s no way an indictment on you, but …” we’d all be at the bottom of the ocean.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Same team. 

I’m not afraid to say “this sucks.” But I’m also cognizant not to take the winds out of the creative sails. I think there’s almost always a way to do both.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: When working with peers there should be a shorthand available

author: BatMeckley
content: (I steer into a lot of rocks)

author: NoahNeedleman
content: You have more plaques

author: BatMeckley
content:
Win some/lose some. 

Also, as you know better than most, I do have a shorthand. You either get an “eh” or a “fucking brilliant” 😂

author: NoahNeedleman
content: But I’d err on the side of “don’t be a dick”

author: Rollmottle
content: one person's "dick" is somebody else's "clear and direct" (ask me how i know). it's an important skill to be able to read the room and tune responses and style without compromising outcomes.

author: BatMeckley
content: There’s definitely been times, especially when I was younger, where I was like “this sucks” and then the song went MASSIVE. And I think the correct response to that is to try and suss out what I missed so I can get it right next time.

author: BatMeckley
content: TLDR: yes the journey matters. But I’m also a big fan of actually getting there.

author: Rob Domos
content: I only ever SRC from the high res version 32 bit versions. The difference between the results would be very very small, and many people here would argue that the difference would be unnoticeable, and maybe they’re right, I’ve never blind tested, but on paper it’s objectively the cleaner way to do it.

author: Rob Domos
content: The only real upside to the extra step would be that SRCing from the 32 and then truncating should be a tiny bit mathematically purer, but most likely nobody would notice either way

author: Berlin
content:
one of my best friends said to me once, “i mean how busy even are you really with mastering?” and that’s when i knew i needed to be clearer about what i do. until then i was being cool, posting barely anything about my mastering work even though it was paying my bills (while everything else was touch and go). so i locked in and changed up my IG. archived everything unrelated to my work and made the whole the account exactly how i want to be seen. even after all that, it was scary and in some ways i felt like i was dishonoring the other parts of myself which i did love. (this was 2018)

years later, i still am a mixed bag, mixing a bunch of songs per year, producing a few per year and still releasing my own work.. still MDing for another band.. but the majority is mastering and I make it known.

author: Rob Domos
content: Literally ever day many times a day. One example is that I do polarity flips on every single alt and it helps me catch a surprising amount of things that could otherwise be missed. I recently caught that one drum mic was muted on an instrumental mix because i heard a bit of snare in the delta. That kind of attention to detail takes an extra minute but solidly increases our certainty of correctness

author: masteredbyjack
content: Just since I don’t think I’ve ever seen a time where a mix was updated and the two mixes would null down to the update

author: Josh Bowman
content: What I was thinking too… ?

author: Rob Domos
content:
I’m flipping the alt mix vs the main mix and the alt master vs the main master. 

Flipping a mix against a master wouldn’t be helpful to me

author: Rob Domos
content: Sure there are times where alts are printed later on an analog recall but this is definitely the minority for me. A vast majority of projects that come in were mixed primarily ITB, and often alts were made using an automated bouncing program that bounces the alts with the non-lim so everything should be the same

author: Rob Domos
content: When flipping the main against the instrumental, I should almost exclusively hear the vocals and any modulating effects. If I flip the instrumental against the main and hear a load of trumpets I’m going to start paying attending and see if there was a bussing issue with their bouncing program. Happens more often than you would think

author: masteredbyjack
content: I see, that makes much more sense. So not listening for a perfect null but things that are out of place. Got it. For me not sure useful over just listening to the alts but I totally see how it could be useful and key on problems quickly

My brain has had to completely change its approach from 15 years ago.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
IMO it's better for the music if it's being mixed at a level and through things that get it as close to final as possible. Decisions can be made with much more intuition within that frame. The vision comes through more clearly. Often. Of course sometimes people wield things in a way that hurts it. But such is life.

Which is not to say big moves aren't still sometimes great. Some of the best mixers I've worked with the moves have been the most drastic. Somewhat confoundingly if the mix is great it can often take more. Or sometimes very little is needed. Hence we listen and try!

author: masteredbyjack
content: The exception would be someone like Heba Kadry or Emily Lazar, who are more transformative but clearly have outstanding taste and ears. There are many ways. But even then I'd think that having the record as close as the team before can get it turns out better for the music

author: Beck Nebel
content: I’m considering streamlining and improving my processes for vocals as I start a full length with an artist I’ve worked with before. Would love to hear how other folks deal with all this. I’m talking about vocal session - rough day-of comps - hand timing - tuning - tracking and lining up/tuning backgrounds (usually lots of em)

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: I assume you're already running Melodyne into AutoTune?

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: Helps to have a record track and just dragging keepers down into the lead/bg/etc tracks that then go into their respective fx chains also

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: but I think that's pretty standard these days

author: Beck Nebel
content: I have the older vocalign and haven’t loved the results I’ve gotten with it in terms of glitchiness. I’m definitely willing to reassess!

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: I find that for short sections at a time, and for really making sure you're selecting the right regions it can be alright

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: There's also a timing alignment to a guide track macro in Melodyne

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: but I still find myself using Vocalign mostly

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: are you using takes and sections of takes that you've agreed on with the artist as being keepers while recording?

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: If you do six songs in a day, that's still an extra hour

author: Beck Nebel
content: I used to do timing in melodyne but haven’t been happy with it lately. I think some of my unhappiness with these timing tools are due to me working in ableton. I produce in ableton and these projects are so unpredictable that bouncing to pro tools ends up just hurting me and stealing my time

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: Also if you're comping while you record, you can do any necessary pickups while the artist is still there and warmed up. If you largely have Verse 2B solid in one take but there are a few words that just aren't there, you have to call the vocalist back in

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: This is also something that the artist needs to be actively engaged in while they're recording too so if they're more used to just singing 5 takes of a section and moving on it may take some time to have that conversation and get in sync

author: Beck Nebel
content: The artist is always happy with my comps so far. I think the issue we run into is that he shows up not knowing the songs well enough and end up needing lots of takes. He’s perfectly happy singing a section 100 times no complaints but the first 20 might be total trash

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: In situations like that I've had good luck starting each new section with loop recording, so they can get the muscle memory up, then moving into being more intentional if they don't already end up with something they like from the loops

author: Beck Nebel
content: The necessary context (maybe) is that it’s an artist who is also somewhat of a celebrity (has too much on his plate), lots of experience recording, only marginally involved in the songwriting and production, so maybe doesn’t take the time to learn the songs well enough

author: Beck Nebel
content: Thanks for this insight, definitely going to try this
